courses.description:
(UGEB1870 is double-coded with EESC1001.)
The course provides an interdisciplinary study of the Earth Systems, including natural phenomena in the atmosphere, hydrosphere, geosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere. The mechanism of these systems, associated dynamics and anthropogenic impacts will be introduced and discussed. The course also serves as a platform to understand and critically assess global environmental change, natural hazards, biodiversity loss, and the water-energy-food nexus, and explore potential technological and policy solutions to these problems. These objectives align strongly with the understanding and pursuit of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, especially SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG#13 Climate Action, SDG#14 Life Below Water, and SDG#15 Life on Land. In addition to attending lectures, students will visit the Jockey Club Museum of Climate Change where it displays the way scientists examine past and current climate and the factors leading to current global temperature change. A geological field excursion will be another highlight of the course to demonstrate the scientific concepts applied to reveal Earth’s tectonic history, evolution and interaction among various spheres. With diverse scientific topics in Earth’s systems, the course shows students how each Earth’s system is interlocking with other spheres and, hence raise the awareness in the importance of sustainability.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC1000.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
Experiential Learning Course
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Describe and explain how the atmosphere, hydrosphere, geosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere interact and how feedback mechanisms operate among the Earth systems.
2. Develop an interdisciplinary approach for investigating Earth system dynamics.
3. Discuss the anthropogenic influences, as well as scientific and technical challenges related to global environmental changes, natural hazards, and the food-water-energy nexus critically.
4. Recognize the complexity of linkages between environmental pressures and human responses related to contemporary sustainable development challenges, contributing to the understanding and pursuit of SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG#13 Climate Action, SDG#14 Life below Water, and SDG#15 Life on Land.
5. Communicate effectively about Earth system and environmental issues in an appropriate science format (i.e. scientific poster and QnA) through working independently and collaboratively.
courses.course_syllabus:
| * ***Lectures***: To provide students basic concepts of different spheres, background information about present environmental phenomena and scientific approaches to study the Earth system * ***Tutorial:*** To guide students critically think about Earth system and related issues to our environment. * ***Visit:*** To show students how professional field works to understand our Earth * ***Field trip:*** To facilitate students observe the environment and interpret and discuss related environmental problems *Note:* Students are expected to attend all lectures, and participate in all tutorials, the visit and the field trip. Meeting with academic advisors can be arranged upon request. **Course Syllabus (English) (Tentative)** The course content will be divided into three parts: **Part I: Geosphere and Cryosphere (Week 1-5)** This component focuses on studying the solid Earth using gravity, electromagnetic and seismic methods. Students will be introduced to the solid physical foundations of the solid Earth, as well as an overview of the structure and composition of the Earth, its materials and constituents, dynamics of its internal and external processes. **Part II: Atmosphere and Climate (Week 7-9)** This compenent covers an integrated introduction to the climate system and the dynamics and chemistry of the atmosphere. Students will learn to explain the history, current state and future projection of weather and climate, natural hazards, and global climate change in the context of natural variability and anthropogenic influence. **Part III: Ecosystem Interactions (Week 10-12)** This compenent covers the interactions of the terrestrial and marine biosphere with the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and geosphere. Students will be introduced to the physical and chemical processes governing the exchange of energy and matter between the biosphere and the environment, addressing related issues such as habitat decline, biodiversity loss, and environmental pollution. | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | | | | | --- | --- | | Week | Topics | | 1 | Course Introduction + The Birth of the Earth | | | Geosphere and Plate Tectonics | | 2 | Marine Geology and Geophysics | | | Tutorial | | 3 | Hong Kong Geology | | | Tutorial | | | **Weekend Field Study** *Group A* | | | **Weekend Field Study** *Group B* | | 4 | Volcanoes | | | Tutorial | | 5 | Cryosphere in A Warming Climate | | | Tutorial | | 6 | English advising talk | | | Tutorial | | 7 | Atmospheric Chemistry | | | Tutorial | | 8 | Global Environmental Change and GHG Emission | | | Tutorial | | 9 | Dynamics of the Earth’s Climate System | | | Tutorial | | 10 | Ecosystem, Climate and (Air) Pollution | | | Tutorial | | 11 | Environmental Biogeochemistry / Environmental toxicology or chemistry | | | Tutorial | | 12 | Oceanography | | | Tutorial | | | **Poster Presentation** | Note: 1. courses.description: The Introductory Practical Course in Earth and Environmental Sciences is a project-based learning experience designed to introduce freshmen to Earth and Environmental Sciences through direct field observation and hands-on project work. This course will be led by 3 instructors in Geology and Geophysics, Atmospheric Sciences and Environmental Sciences. By exploring the geology beneath our feet, the atmospheric currents above us, and the environmental issues that surround us, students will gain a holistic understanding of our planet.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Introduction to Hong Kong Geology:

* Able to read the basic information from a geological map
* Gain a brief understanding in major rock types in Hong Kong
* Understanding the geological history of Hong Kong
* Able to correlate the map information, outcrop properties and the landscape

2. Atmospheric Science - Earth’s Rotation and Weather:

* Describe the basic principles of Earth's rotation and the Coriolis effect and their influence on global weather patterns.
* Evaluate the impact of the Coriolis effect on weather systems, including the rotation of tropical cyclones, using meteorological data.
* Design and conduct laboratory experiments to apply theoretical knowledge of atmospheric science to simulate and analyze real-world weather phenomena.

3. Environmental Science - Water Quality:

* Summarize the key indicators of water quality and discuss their implications for ecosystem health and human well-being.
* Design and perform experiments to collect and assess water samples, measuring parameters such as pH, turbidity, and pollutants to determine water quality.
* Assess the sources and consequences of water pollution and propose viable solutions for improving water quality based on scientific evidence.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Introduction to Hong Kong Geology: This field study takes students to a geologically interesting field area in Hong Kong, providing an outdoor classroom to understand geological processes. Students will learn practical field skills in identifying the rocks, reading geological maps, and understanding how the Earth’s processes shape the landscape.

* Atmospheric Science - Earth’s Rotation and Weather: This part is designed to introduce students to the fundamental concepts of Earth's rotation and the Coriolis effect, and their impact on our weather such as the rotation of tropical cyclones. Through a combination of theoretical lectures and laboratory experiments, students will gain a comprehensive understanding of these phenomena.

* Environmental Science - Water Quality: This practical study immerses students in the field of environmental science with a focus on water quality. Students will collect and analyze water samples from various sources, testing for parameters like pH, turbidity, and presence of pollutants. This project will underscore the importance of clean, healthy water for ecosystems and human societies, illustrating environmental challenges and potential solutions.

courses.title: Fundamental Earth and Environmental Field Study I
courses.description: EESC2009 is a fundamental field-based course introducing elementary concepts of past Earth’s processes and environmental changes. It also covers important aspects of plate tectonics, different rock types, geological deformation, geomorphology and environmental changes, natural hazards and human impacts. The principal goal of this course is to let students understand how the present geological records and landforms reveal the past tectonic movements and affect the human urban planning. Students are trained to observe, describe and discuss field features, with the help of field tools (e.g. compasses-clinometer and GPS receiver). Basic skills of field techniques, interpreting geologic maps and making field notes are introduced to assist students acquiring field data and discuss possible geologic processes. A field report from each group is required to summarize the field study logically. Field locations of this course may change from year to year. All students are welcome, but priority will be given to students who have taken EESC1001.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken EESC2110 or ESSC2110.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:

1. Recognition of different lithological units (including sedimentary, metamorphic, igneous rocks) and coastal features in the field

2. Using field equipment, such as GPS receivers and Compass-clinometer

3. Be familiar with the techniques of field data acquisition and analysis

4. Evaluating an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle

5. Working independently and discussing with teammates

6. Summarizing information in a clear, concise and logical manner in the individual field notes and group reports

courses.description: This course presents an integrated introduction to the solid earth system stressing the geological, chemical, physical, and biological interactions among the lithosphere, hydrosphere and cryosphere. The course applies basic scientific and mathematical concepts to explain the history and behaviour of the solid earth system. Geophysical and geochemical techniques for probing the interior of the earth are reviewed. Plate tectonics is introduced as a unifying theme to understand geodynamic processes. The course includes discussions of topics that are relevant to society, resources and sustainability, such as the physical and chemical basis of natural hazards (earthquakes, tsunami, landslides) and their mitigation, and the impact of geological processes on the global environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC2010.
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will contribute to the understanding of the dynamics of the solid Earth system, specifically the lithosphere, hydrosphere and cryosphere, as well as their interaction. The students should be able to: 1) describe and use the scientific process, explain how theories are built upon earth system observations, and how both are tested and revised; 2) explain how fundamental physical, chemical, and biological principles govern specific earth system processes; 3) participate knowledgeably and intelligently in discussions of public policy related to earth system science, particularly with respect to natural hazards, resources, environment and sustainable development; 4) work effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.

courses.description: This course presents an integrated introduction to the climate system, stressing the dynamics of the atmosphere and its physical and chemical interactions with the hydrosphere, biosphere and geosphere. The course applies basic scientific and mathematical principles to explain the history, current state and future projection of weather and climate, natural hazards (e.g., typhoons, floods), and global climate change in the context of natural variability and anthropogenic influence. Topics include Earth’s energy balance, climate feedback, convection and clouds, general circulation of the atmosphere and ocean, biogeochemistry and global carbon cycle, roles of vegetation and ecosystems, and historical and future climate change. Student taking this course are expected to have taken PHYS1111, CHEM1070 and MATH1010 or equivalent.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC2020.
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will contribute to the understanding of the dynamics of the climate system, specifically the atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere and solid earth, as well as their interactions. The students should be able to: 1) describe and use the scientific processes, explain how theories are built upon earth system observations, and how both are tested and revised; 2) explain how fundamental physical and chemical principles govern specific climate system processes; 3) participate knowledgeably and intelligently in discussions of public policy related to earth system science, particularly with respect to extreme weather events, global climate change and sustainable development; 4) work effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Topics**

Introduction; overview of the climate system

* *Part** **I: Energy Balance of the Earth**

Basic radiation physics; energy balance of the Earth; greenhouse effect

Simple climate model; radiative forcing, climate sensitivity and climate feedback

* *Lab 1:** Climate sensitivity and feedback in a simple climate model

Climate variability and climate change; roles of aerosols; meridional structure of the atmosphere

* *Part** **II: Dynamics of the Atmosphere**

Vertical structure of the atmosphere; Newton’s second law; pressure and hydrostatic balance; barometric law

Convection; first law of thermodynamics; dry adiabatic lapse rate; atmospheric stability

Potential temperature; water content in air; moist convection and cloud formation

* *Lab 2:** Conservation of angular momentum on a rotating Earth

Coriolis force; pressure gradient force; horizontal momentum equations; geostrophic balance

Thermal wind balance; atmospheric fronts and jet stream; surface friction and ageostrophic flow

General circulation of the atmosphere; Hadley circulation in the tropics; baroclinic eddies and midlatitude weather systems

* *Lab 3:** Introduction to weather analysis and forecast

* *Field** **trip to** **Hong Kong Observatory**

* *Part** **III: Ocean and Climate**

Overview of ocean circulation; Ekman transport and wind-driven circulation

Effect of Ekman transport on the interior ocean; western boundary currents; thermohaline circulation

Ocean heat buffer and transport; El Niño-Southern Oscillation; tropical cyclones

* *Part** **IV:** **Ecosystems** **and Climate**

Fluxes in biosphere-atmosphere interactions; surface energy balance; evapotranspiration and photosynthesis; biogeophysical feedbacks

Biogeochemical reservoirs and residence times; carbon and nutrient cycling in ecosystems; geological carbon cycle

Contemporary carbon cycle; marine carbonate chemistry; biological bump; ocean biogeochemical feedbacks

* *Lab 4**: Global carbon cycle

Global carbon budget; terrestrial carbon sink and biogeochemical feedbacks

* *Part** **V:** **Past,** **Present** **and Future Climate**

Climate throughout Earth’s history; atmosphere of the early Earth; from Cretaceous to ice ages; recent 20,000 years

Recent climate change: observations and attribution

Future climate projections; impacts of climate change; where do we go from here?

courses.description: This course covers basic computation skills which are important to modern Earth and Environmental Sciences research and data analysis. Topics include the basic Python language syntax; programming flow control; usage of functions; file input/output modules; data visualisation; atmospheric science applications; geoscience applications and basic machine learning applications in earth and environmental sciences. Python 3 will be used throughout the course. Examples and tutorials will be based on various problems in Earth and Environmental Sciences using actual observational or in-situ data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CSCI1040, CSCI2040 or ESSC2030.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will obtain basic skills in coding for the tasks in different earth science problems. This includes data acquisition, selection and manipulation in geophysical and environmental problems. They will also learn specific Python modules in science applications.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Installation and Basics
* Methods, Functions, and Numpy
* Booleans, If-then-else Statement
* For Loop and While Loop, Try-except
* Self-defined Functions, Programming Style
* File IO with Pandas and Xarray
* Data Visualization with Matplotlib
* Scientific Computing with Scipy

courses.description: EESC2110 is a fundamental field-based course introducing elementary concepts of past Earth’s processes and environmental changes. It also covers important aspects of plate tectonics, different rock types, geological deformation, geomorphology and environmental changes, natural hazards and human impacts. The principal goal of this course is to let students understand how the present geological records and landforms reveal the past tectonic movements and affect the human urban planning. Students are trained to observe, describe and discuss field features, with the help of field tools (e.g. compasses-clinometer and GPS receiver). Basic skills of field techniques, interpreting geologic maps and making field notes are introduced to assist students acquiring field data and discuss possible geologic processes. A field report from each group is required to summarize the field study logically. Field locations of this course may change from year to year. All students are welcome, but priority will be given to students who have taken EESC1001.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC2110.

courses.description: Field study of current landform and geological features is the key to reveal past Earth’s processes and environmental changes. This also provides data for further studies on natural hazards. EESC2119 is an intermediate level, field-based course of the Earth and Environmental Sciences Programme. It covers important aspects of atmospheric sciences, plate tectonics, volcanoes, deformation structures, sedimentology, coastal features, earthquakes and associated present-day infrastructures. The principal goal of this course is to let students study major atmospheric sciences, geological features and understand how tectonic movement and atmospheric phenomenon contribute to the current different landforms, disasters and urban planning. Students are trained to observe, describe and discuss field features. Basic skills of using field tools (e.g. compasses-clinometer), studying geologic maps and making field notes are introduced to help students acquire field data and analyze possible atmospheric phenomenon and geologic processes. A field report is required to summarize the field study logically. The field location and term of offer of this course may change from year to year. Due to limited quota, priority will be given to students who have taken EESC2010 and passed the pre-enrolment quiz.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Intermediate Geosciences Field Study II

meetings.instructor: Dr. TAM Pui Yuk

courses.description:
EESC2129 is designed to provide students with fundamental geological field techniques and the application of geological and environmental concepts specific to the region of Hong Kong. The course aims to deepen students' understanding of the local geology, including its formation processes, tectonic history, and its relationship with the environment. By the end of the course, students will have acquired a solid background in local geology and geomorphology. The course emphasizes hands-on training and practical skills development. Students will learn essential geological field techniques, including map reading, gathering geological data, making field observations, and jotting geological field notes. They will also develop critical thinking skills through the analysis and interpretation of geological data. Additionally, the course includes training in life-saving skills to ensure students' safety during fieldwork. EESC2129 consists of a 10-day local field study and five pre-trip lectures. The field study provides an immersive experience where students will directly apply the knowledge and techniques learned in the classroom to real geological settings in Hong Kong. The pre-trip lectures serve as a preparatory phase, covering relevant theoretical concepts, field methodologies, and safety protocols. Following the field study, two post-trip discussions will provide an opportunity for students to share their findings, and engage in further analysis and interpretation. Successful completion of EESC2129 requires continuous teamwork and independent assignments. Students will be expected to collaborate with their peers during fieldwork, share responsibilities, and contribute to group discussions. Additionally, independent assignments will be assigned to reinforce students' understanding of the course material and encourage individual exploration of specific geological topics.

Note: This course may involve physical activities and fieldwork in outdoor environments. Students are advised to comply with safety guidelines, follow instructions from instructors, and maintain appropriate fitness levels to ensure a safe and enriching learning experience.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) and with instructor's approval.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:

1. Understanding Hong Kong’s fundamental geological history, lithology, structures, mineral forming processes and landforms.
2. Studying different local lithological units (including sedimentary, metamorphic, igneous rocks) in the field.
3. Using field equipment, such as geological compasses, to acquire field data.
4. Producing geological field notes.
5. Discussing and analysing the field observation critically based on evidence and scientific principle.
6. Summarizing information in a clear, concise and logical manner in the field notes and group reports to understand geologic processes, paleo-environments and present geomorphology.
7. Working independently and self-study.
8. Work in a team and discuss with teammates.
courses.course_syllabus:
5 Pre-trip lectures & Practical sessions:

* General Introduction of HK geology
* Field Safety
* Introduction to Igneous Rocks, Sedimentary Rocks, Metamorphic Rocks and Geological Structures in Hong Kong

10-day Field study:

* 6 sites of Igneous Rocks and associated landforms
* 2 sites of Sedimentary Rocks and associated paleo-environments and coastal features
* 2 sites of Metamorphic Rocks and structures and deformation history

2 Post-trip discussion sessions:

* Discussing field data
* Discussing on group projects

* Course evaluation: Tailored questionnaire to be answered by all students at the end of the course.
* Discussion with students: view and suggestions will be gathered from students.
* Reflection of teacher

courses.description: EESC2160 is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of minerals as fundamental building blocks of the Earth, their chemistry, occurrence, physical and chemical features, crystallography, as well as the formation and uses of naturally formed minerals, oil, and gas. The course also covers mining processes and management, exploring the interaction between natural resources and the environment, and their impact on the biological system. The course teaches students chemistry in the Solid Earth, occurrence, exploration and usage of natural resources like minerals, gas and oil. The course trains students with skills of identifying physical properties and chemical properties of natural forming minerals. Teachers will introduce techniques and technology in mining and extracting natural resources. Areas of interaction between natural resources and the environment, as well as the management of natural resources, will be elaborated in student’s problem-based learning sessions. Students are expected to equip knowledge and skills in understanding the real-world scenarios of the natural resources, and problem-solving skills in resource management practices and decision-making processes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, students will be able to:

* Describe the rock-forming minerals in terms of their chemistry, structural characteristics, and physical properties.
* Discuss the relationship between the chemical composition, structural features, and physical properties of minerals.
* Describe the mineral assemblages commonly found in igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks.
* Understand the formation processes and practical applications of natural resources, including minerals, oil, and gas.
* Gain knowledge of mining processes and management techniques, including environmental considerations.
* Analyze the interaction between natural resources and the environment, as well as their impact on biological systems.
* Develop problem-solving skills through the application of natural resource management principles.
courses.course_syllabus:
Course Content:

1. Chemistry in the Solid Earth

2. Minerals Formation and Exploration

3. Physical and Mineral Properties of Naturally Formed Minerals

4. Uses of Naturally Occurring Minerals

5. Oil and Gas Formation and Exploration

6. Interaction between Natural Resources and the Environment

7. Interaction between Natural Resources and Biological Systems

8. Problem-Based Learning of Natural Resources and Management

courses.description: This course deals with the relationships between living organisms, resources and environment. The basic multidisciplinary concepts of sustainable development, human population and health risk, conservation of resources, climate change, environmental degradation, pollution control, biodiversity, solid waste and waste water management, etc, will be introduced. Concepts of think globally, act locally will be introduced the importance of acting as a global citizen to help solving environmental problems with an innovative mind to design new policy or technology. Case studies and field trips are included to illustrate various environmental issues using a multidisciplinary approach with emphasis on how modern technology can have significant societal impacts and responsibility.

courses.title: Environmental Chemistry

meetings.instructor: Professor LEE Hung Kay
Professor LEE Hung Kay
Professor LEE Hung Kay

courses.description: This is a foundation course designed to equip students with a proper understanding of the fundamental aspects of environmental chemistry. It introduces the basic concept of chemical equilibrium and kinetics, the nature and characteristics of various common types of air and water pollution arising from industrial, agricultural and domestic sources. It outlines the principles of measurement for various parameters commonly used for air and water pollution studies, their significance and limitations. It also examines various types of aerial emission arising from combustion and industrial processes, and vehicles, and their chemical interaction leading to various global environmental issues such as the formation of photochemical smog, depletion of ozone layer and global warming effects.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC2515. Pre-requisite: EESC2270 or ENSC2270 or permission of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students who have finished this course are expected to understand:

1. some basic concepts in chemistry ranging from atomic structure and chemical bonding to the basic principle of coordination chemistry of the transition metals, and thermodynamics and kinetics.
2. aquatic chemistry which includes solubility, acid-base reactions, complexation equilibria, and redox reactions.
3. the chemistry of common pollutants in natural water systems.
4. atmospheric chemistry with emphasis on chemical and photochemical processes occurring in the atmosphere.
5. the chemistry of common air pollutants.
6. the chemistry of soil including its composition, essential nutrients in soil, the chemistry of fertilizers, and acid-base and ion-exchange reactions in soil.

Student will understand key ideas on these topics and understand various local and global environmental problems through a case-study approach.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Some basic concepts in chemistry

3. Water pollution
4. Atmospheric chemistry
5. Air pollution
6. Environmental Geochemistry

courses.description: This is a foundation chemistry laboratory course designed to accompany EESC2515. This course illustrates the fundamental principles and basic techniques in general environmental chemistry. Laboratory work covers a range of experiments, including acid-base reactions, chemical thermodynamics and kinetics, complexation equilibria, coordination chemistry of the transition metals, and analysis of air pollutants. Students who finish this course are expected to be familiar with the general techniques in conducting chemistry experiments and the use of simple instruments such as IR and UV–Vis spectrophotometers. They will also learn how to design of experiments and report experimental data in scientific reports. The assessment scheme of this course is based on students' performance in conducting experiments and report writing.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC2517. Co-requisite: EESC2515 or ENSC2515 or permission of the instructor.
courses.course_syllabus:
Experiment List:

1. Synthesis of Alum Crystals from Scrap Metal
2. Rates of Chemical Reactions
3. Alkalinity of Water
4. Total Phosphorus Content in Polluted Water
5. Determination of the Iron Content in a Vitamin Tablet
6. (a) Tyndall Effect in Starch and Gelatin Colloids, (b) Infra-Red Analysis of CuC12-DMSO Complex
7. Determination of Total Aldehydes in Indoor Environment with Impinger Sampling
8. Sampling of NOx (NO+NO2) and Particulates

2. Feedback from demonstrators and teaching assistants

4. Discussion with students: view and suggestions will be gathered from students
5. Reflection of teacher

courses.description: The course provides a survey of elementary analytical quantitative and qualitative methods commonly used in earth and environmental sciences, with applications in geophysics, geophysical/environmental fluid dynamics, as well as related aspects in thermodynamics and wave physics. Teaching aided by numerical programming is adopted and emphasized, in addition to analytical understanding of these methods. Typical examples include heat conduction on earth surface, seismic and ocean waves, air pollution, geodynamics, and atmospheric dynamics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: (MATH1520 or MATH1010) or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. An understanding of elementary quantitative methods used in earth and environmental sciences.
2. Appreciation of how physical principles in earth and environmental sciences are formulated quantitatively,
3. Knowledge of the application of elementary methods in solving problems in earth and environmental sciences.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basic solid Mechanics: Equation of motions of solid, Hooke’s law, plane strain and plane stress problems, Airy stress function (biharmonic equations), bending of beam and plates (nonhomogeneous biharmonic equation), Solution method of elasticity, Helmholtz decomposition theorem for displacement field, use of gradient, divergence and curl in formulating Lame strain potential and Love’s potential.
2. Geodynamics: Heat conduction in earth, Fourier law of heat conduction, error functions, instantaneous cooling of the half-space, age of the earth; lithospheric bending and folding.
3. Seismicity: single degree of oscillator, response spectrum, Helmholtz decomposition for velocity vectors, use of gradient, divergence and curl in formulating compression and shear wave equations. Rayleigh wave as surface wave; 2-D waves versus 3-D waves; Analysis of seismic signals using Fourier transforms, physical meaning of phase shift, physical meaning of Fourier transform magnitude.
4. Basic fluid Mechanics: Circulation and vorticity, Helmholtz theorem, Kelvin circulation theorem and their implications, conservation of mass, derivation of Navier-Stokes equation, stream function for potential flow theory;
5. Geophysical flows: Coriolis force as function of latitude, geophysical scaling, Rossby number, Ekman number, and Reynold’s number; turbulent diffusion in fluids and atmosphere, Duhamel integral for time varying boundary condition, Taylor’s point source solution (1-D, 2-D and 3-D cases), pollutant diffusion in river, ocean, and atmosphere; Ogata-Banks solution; Gaussian plume model for smoke diffusion; Kelvin-Helmholtz instability.
6. Atmospheric flows: vortex models, maximum wind speed in tornadoes, maximum wind speed in typhoons, eyewall dynamics, buoyance instability in atmosphere; Taylor-Proudman theorem; radiative transfer equation (integro-differentiation equation) and climate change, use of radiative transfer model in remote sensing data assimilation and numerical weather forecast.
7. Ocean waves: Perturbation theory and Stokes wave theory, stream functions, Airy’s wave theory, shallow water and deep- water limits, dispersion relation, shallow water equation, conical theory for ocean waves, solitary wave or solitons. storm surges (inverse barometer effect, moving depression effect, wind-induced surge).
courses.feedback_evaluation:
* Course evaluation: Tailored questionnaire to be answered by all students at the end of the course.
* Discussion with students – views and suggestions will be gathered at least two times during the term.
* Reflection of teacher.

* Chau K.T. (2018). Theory of Differential Equations in Engineering and Mechanics, CRC Press, Boca Raton.
* Chau K.T. (2019). Applications of Differential Equations in Engineering and Mechanics, CRC Press, Boca Raton.

courses.description: This is a multidisciplinary course introducing the fundamental physical, chemical and biological principles necessary for understanding the natural and built environments, with an emphasis on reliable water and food supplies, pollution mitigation, waste management, energy resources, climate change, and sustainable development. Examples of engineering solutions to tackle some of these resource and environmental issues are presented. Field trips are included to illustrate interesting case studies. Topics include: conservation principles for mass, energy and momentum in the environmental systems; basic environmental chemistry, hydrology and ecology; risk assessment; and basic principles of water resource engineering, solid waste treatment, noise pollution, air pollution control, climate change adaptation and mitigation, and the interplay between energy consumption and the environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC2800. Pre-requisite: MATH1010 or 1510 or 1520.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Understand the basic physical, chemical and biological principles governing the various resource and environmental issues of our society.
* Be able to use basic mathematical methods to assess environmental risks and the feasibility of various engineering solutions to resource and environmental problems.
* Be able to participate knowledgeably and intelligently in discussion of public policy related to global and regional resource and environmental issues including the food-water-energy crisis, water and air pollution, global climate change, and hazardous wastes.
* Be able to work effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.
courses.course_syllabus:
L01 Introduction

L02 Mass Transfer

L03 Energy Transfer

L04 Environmental Chemistry

L05 Mathematics for Growth

L06 Risk Assessment

L07 Water Pollution I

L08 Water Pollution II

L09 Water Quality Control

L10 Air Pollution

L11 Waste Management

L12 Noise Pollution

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Environmental Sciences Field Study I
courses.description: This intensive 1-2 week, 1 credit course provides a unique opportunity for students to go on a comprehensive field trip to Southeast Asia or Belt and Road countries. The journey is designed to offer students a firsthand understanding of environmental sciences and the pressing issues that are currently shaping its discourse. Students will engage in an immersive ecotour, visiting diverse ecosystems, conservation sites, and areas grappling with environmental challenges. The trip aims to expose students to the realities of environmental science, allowing them to witness the dynamic interplay of ecological, socio-political, and economic factors that influence environmental policies and practices.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: EESC2270.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will:

* Gain a deep understanding of the environmental issues faced by regions in Southeast Asia or Belt and Road countries.
* Develop an appreciation for the complexity of environmental problems and the multifaceted approaches required to address them.
* Understand the importance of community engagement and policy in environmental conservation.
* Apply theoretical knowledge in real-world contexts, fostering critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Ecological Exploration: Students will visit various ecosystems, including rainforests, coastal areas, and mountain regions, to understand different environmental processes and biodiversity.
* Real-World Engagement: Students will explore sites experiencing significant environmental challenges, such as deforestation, urbanization, and climate change, to gain insight into real-world problems and potential solutions.

* Conservation Efforts: Site visits to conservation projects and discussions with local environmental organizations will provide an understanding of the strategies employed to protect and restore the environment.
* Cultural Immersion: The field trip will also include cultural immersion, helping students appreciate the local cultures and understand the role of communities in environmental stewardship.
* Interdisciplinary Learning: The course integrates environmental science with aspects of sociology, economics, and political science, promoting a holistic understanding of environmental issues and strategies.

* Discussion with students: view and suggestions will be gathered from students.
* Reflection of teacher

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Analytical Methods for Earth and Environmental Sciences
courses.description: The course provides a survey of various analytical techniques commonly employed in solving problems encountered in earth and environmental sciences. Typical examples include heat conduction on earth surface, seismic and ocean waves, air pollution, geodynamics, and atmospheric dynamics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC3020. Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) and (EESC2020 or ESSC2020), and (MATH2550), and (PHYS1001 or 1002 or 1111 or 1113), or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. An understanding of the assumptions and limitations of the analytical methods commonly employed in modeling and solving problems encountered in earth and environmental sciences.
2. Knowledge of the techniques used in solving these mathematical models associated with earth and environmental sciences.
3. An appreciation of the application of analytic methods in tackling various problems in earth and environmental sciences.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Introduction
* Heat flow in solid earth. Turbulent diffusion of pollutants in fluids. Transient flow in hydrology.
* Wave propagation in seismology and oceanography. Gravity field of the Earth. Potential flows in fluid mechanics and seepage
* Atmospheric flows in tornadoes and cyclones. Geophysical fluid flows in oceans, including storm surge and Ekman transport
* Plate bending and lithospheric flexure, folding and Stokes flow.
* Fourier series and transform in analyzing seismographs and other time series.

courses.description: This course is an important part of the core Earth and Environmental Sciences Curriculum. It introduces the processes and products of rock deformation in three dimensions, ranging from micro- (micron) to macro- (kilometer) scales. It discusses geometries and mechanism of faults, folds, structural features of igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks, and superposed deformations and introduces regional deformational history and tectonics. Structural geology in the field of resource exploration (petroleum and mineral deposits) is also introduced. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise and demonstrations as well as field trips to local or overseas outcrops.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC3100. Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010 or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:
1. Understand the geometry of different geological structures
2. Use concepts of solid mechanics to interpret the kinematics and geometries of geological structure formation
3. Use graphical tools to compile and interpret structural data
4. Integrate topics in structural geology and plate tectonics through survey of scientific literatures
5. Make primary observations in the field and using them to construct and test structural hypotheses

Lectures focus on geometric, kinematic, and mechanical analysis of geological structures. Labs use geological maps, computers, stereonets, and physical analogs to illustrate these concepts. Students are encouraged to lead discussion of leading geological topics spread throughout the semester, each of which integrates recent class topics with large-scale active tectonics. Field trips in the second half of the semester encourage small-group discussion of observations and interpretations of deformational history of the field working area.

The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Geoscience Field Course
courses.description: Understanding of Earth processes and environmental changes over geological time is highly dependent upon the experience and capabilities gained through doing fieldwork. EESC3110 is an intermediate level course of the Earth and Environmental Sciences Programme. It covers important aspects of field geology, including sedimentary, igneous and metamorphic petrology, tectonics, geophysics and surficial processes. The principal goal of this course is to train students to recognize different lithological units and their geometries in three dimensions, and understand the related tectonic environment and formation mechanism. Class lectures introduce basic skills of reading and interpreting geological maps, using geological equipment (i.e. Compass-clinometer, GPS receiver), and producing field notes and reports. Field projects include field observation and description, techniques of field data acquisition and analysis, sample collection, and geological map compilation. Field projects also focus on surficial processes (relatively occurring on short geological time scale), which are of environmental and ecological importance. The field location (either in mainland of China or overseas) may change from year to year.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC3110. Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010), and (EESC3100 or ESSC3100) or (EESC4120 or ESSC4120) or by instructor’s approval.
courses.component:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:

1. Gain the basic skills of field work in geosciences.
2. Recognize different lithological units in the field, including sedimentary, metamorphic, volcanic and plutonic complexes.
3. Measure the geometry of different geological structures in variable scales.
4. Know how to use field equipment, such as GPS receivers and Compass-clinometer.
5. Be familiar with the techniques of field data acquisition and analysis.
6. Understand the standards of sample collection and description.
7. Be able to make field reports and compile a simple geological map.
8. Gain the capabilities of individual or team-oriented geological field work.

The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 3-4 pre-field lectures/tutorials for introducing geological background of the studied field area.
2. 10-12 days of field study and laboratory visit.
3. Individual field notes and reports are required.

* **Note:*** *Contents may vary depending on some conditions such as weather and safely.*

courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts of the physics of the Earth to understand how the solid Earth works. Since 1960s, plate tectonics has been developed to explain observations on Earth such as mountain building, occurrence of earthquakes and volcanoes, as well as deposition of natural resources. The discovery of plate tectonics requires understanding of geophysical methods, which will be covered in this course. The topics covered include the Earth’s gravitational and magnetic fields, earthquake seismology, internal structure of the Earth, thermal and electrical properties, as well as geodynamics. Methods of geophysical survey will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC3120. Pre-requisite: EESC 2010 or ESSC2010 or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to know about Earth’s inner structure, composition, and thermal and electrical properties, understand principles of seismic wave propagation and earthquake physics, gain knowledge of gravity and geomagnetism, and have the ability to analyze the observation data for explanation of geophysical processes. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Plate tectonics: Magnetic field, Paleomagnetism, Plate motion and rotation

Seismology: Earthquakes and plate boundaries, Earthquake location and magnitude, Earthquake energy and

focal mechanism, Wave propagation, Refraction and reflection seismology

Gravity: Gravity and geoid, Gravity corrections, Gravity anomaly, Isostasy

Heat: Heat flow, Heat conduction, Heat convection

courses.title: Introduction to Seismic Data Processing

meetings.instructor: Professor TAN Yen Joe

courses.description: This course that will be offered in the summer term aims to develop the students’ knowledge, skills, and interest in seismology, scientific computing, and seismic data processing. Topics include introduction to Linux command line, shell scripting, and Generic Mapping Tools (GMT); introduction to Seismic Analysis Code (SAC); how to use the various Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology (IRIS) tools for data request and initial data exploration; and various methods to model and visualize seismic waveforms for earthquake and velocity structure studies.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will obtain basic skills in seismic data acquisition, processing, visualizing, and modeling that are fundamental to the field of seismology.
courses.course_syllabus:
Each week, a learning module will be assigned to the students for completion. This includes watching pre-recorded lectures and completing specific assignments to demonstrate their grasp of the lecture materials. There will be a final project where students will integrate what they have learnt throughout the semester to gain new scientific insights from analyzing seismic data.

* Linux command line
* Shell scripting
* Generic Mapping Tools (GMT) for plotting seismicity and velocity models
* Seismic Analysis Code (SAC) for seismic data visualization, processing, and analysis
* Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology (IRIS) tools for data request and initial data exploration
* Seismic data visualization and modelling for earthquake source and velocity structure studies
* ObsPy: Python toolbox for seismology
* Jupyter Notebooks for code and results sharing

courses.description: EESC3140 is designed to introduce students to the global distribution of elements and the chemistry of natural Earth's materials. The course focuses on understanding the chemical processes operating within the solid Earth and other planets, spanning from the past to the present. Emphasis is placed on developing quantitative and analytical skills in geochemistry. The course covers a wide range of topics, including fundamental principles of geochemical processes, thermal dynamics, phase transitions and the relationship between pressure, temperature, and composition in different geological materials, major elements, trace elements, rare Earth elements, element mobility and mineral stability, and the roles of different elements in Earth’s evolution. The course also introduces the role of minerals and rocks in supporting and influencing life and, how biological processes affect the chemical composition of Earth’s atmosphere, hydrosphere, and lithosphere. Students will be trained to acquire a comprehensive understanding of the formation and interaction of materials within the Earth. Students will learn about the geochemical processes involved and their implications for potential tectonic settings and surficial processes. By studying geochemical data and engaging in practical sessions, students will develop the skills to analyze and interpret the geochemical data, allowing them to discuss paleo-environments with possible tectonic models such as seafloor spreading, subduction and mountain building regimes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) or (EESC2130 or ESSC2130 or EESC2119 or EESC2129) or (EESC3100 or ESSC3100)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:

1. Understanding the chemical processes operating within the solid Earth.
2. Applying geochemical concepts and techniques to real-world scenarios
3. Discussing and interpreting paleo environments using possible tectonic models, fostering critical thinking and problem-solving skills
4. Summarizing information in a clear, concise and logical manner in the assignments and exams to understand geologic processes, paleo-environments and present geomorphology
5. Working independently and self-study
6. Working in a team and discuss with teammates.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics cover:

* Introduction to geochemistry (global distribution of elements) (1)
* Thermal dynamics (2)
* Phase rules + phase diagrams (8)
* Major elements
* Trace elements
* Rare Earth Elements (2)
* Oxidation and reduction (2)
* Stable isotopes (2)
* Radioactive isotopes (Geochronology) (2)
* Geobiochemistry (1)
* Environmental geochemistry (1)

courses.description: This course introduces observations of and physical principles governing the circulation of the Earth’s atmosphere in relation to weather and climate. The topics covered include atmospheric composition and structure, convection, fundamentals of atmospheric motions, and the basic principles for weather and climate modeling. Physical principles covered include basic conservation laws, balanced flows, atmospheric thermodynamics, circulation and vorticity, atmospheric waves, and theories for various weather systems.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1) Pre-requisite: (EESC2020 or ESSC2020) or (MATH2550 or EESC2520 or PHYS2051) or permission of instructor.
2) Not for students who have taken ESSC3200.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Basic conservation laws
+ Fundamental forces, rotating frame, spherical coordinate, continuity equation, thermodynamic equation
* Elementary applications of basics equations
+ Scale analysis, hydrostatic approximation, isobaric coordinates
* Thermodynamics,
+ Gas laws, 1st and 2nd laws of thermodynamics, convection
* Circulation and vorticity
+ Kevin circulation theorem, vorticity, Ertel potential vorticity
* Atmospheric waves
+ Perturbation method, gravity waves, Rossby waves
* Introduction to qusai-geostrophic theory
+ Qusai-geostrophic approximation, baroclinic disturbances
* Weather systems
+ Extratropical cyclones

courses.description: This course introduces the physical and chemical processes determining the composition for the atmosphere and its implications for climate, ecosystems, air pollution and human welfare. Topics covered include atmospheric structure, atmospheric chemistry models, atmospheric transport, chemical kinetics, stratospheric and tropospheric chemistry, chemistry of aerosols, biogeochemical cycles, as well as critical environmental issues including stratospheric ozone depletion, acid rain, photochemical smog, and climate change.

courses.description: This course discusses from a multidisciplinary viewpoint the anthropogenic causes of environmental degradation and the various approaches to environmental protection and pollution control. Students are introduced the concept of sustainability in environmental protection, economic measures and voluntary approach in environmental management, control and treatment technologies, and their comparative effectiveness in the abatement of various types of pollution. Management programmes and control strategies in tackling local environmental problems are illustrated.

courses.description: This course will investigate the characteristics and dynamics of the ocean. Specific topics include ocean floor, marine sediments, oceanic plate, seawater, air-sea interaction, ocean circulation, waves, El Niño-Southern Oscillation, and the roles of the ocean in climate and climate variability.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC3300. Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) and (EESC2020 or ESSC2020), or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, the students will
1) Gain knowledge of the physical, chemical and biological process associated with the ocean,
2) Understand fundamental physic of phenomena related to the ocean,
3) Develop ability to analyze and explain observed oceanic phenomena.

(Course outcomes as related to Programme Learning Outcomes) -- The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Ocean floor and seafloor mapping
* Oceanic plate and crust
* Mid-ocean ridges and seismic reflection imaging
* Marine sediments
* Properties of sea water, mixed layer and thermocline
* Ocean general circulation, ocean heat transport
* Geostrophic and hydrostatic balance, vorticity
* Wind-driven circulation, western boundary current, Sverdrup theory
* Thermohaline circulation
* Inertial oscillations, surface waves, Rossby waves, Kelvin waves,
* Climate variability, El Nino-Southern Oscillation, Paleoclimate

courses.description: This course introduces the physical and chemical principles of hydrogeology. Concepts of surface and groundwater hydrology, as well as quantitative modelling of groundwater flow and contaminant transport are covered. Special topics on the coupling of hydrologic and geologic processes will also be addressed, with examples from tectonics, petroleum geology, geothermics, and global change.

The students will appreciate the interaction between the hydrosphere and geosphere, and its impact on natural resources and the environment. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Biogeochemistry
courses.description: This course aims to take students to explore recent advances in biogeochemistry of different elements in both terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. The course will include basic concepts of watershed processes, elemental cycling, hydrological transport, atmospheric processes, and oceanic transformation. The applications of the knowledge on environmental pollution and environmental health will be discussed, different cutting-edge techniques and hands-on field approaches will be covered in this course, with an emphasis on aquatic habitats.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC3330. Pre-requisite: (EESC2270 or ENSC2270) or (EESC2020 or ESSC2020) or GRMD2209, or permission of the instructors.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:

1. understand the key processes regulating elemental cycling in the environment.
2. understand the basic concepts and recent development in environmental biogeochemistry and its relationships to major global environmental problems.
3. know how to design and conduct simple investigation of elemental cycling in the environment
4. know how to communicate with the general public with a scientific understanding of biogeochemistry.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course presents the recent understanding and advancements in global biogeochemistry. The lectures are on a range of topics, covering major elemental cycles in forest, streams, groundwater, wetlands, inland waters, oceans, and atmosphere. Advanced concepts of application of biogeochemistry will further be discussed with an emphasis on environmental pollution and health, and global climate change. The fundamentals of major elemental cycles like carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, oxygen, sulphur, mercury and silicate will also be covered.

| Week 1 | Introduction; overview of global environmental problems and key elements; basics of environmental chemistry | Tsui |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Week 2 | Watershed processes: forests, streams, groundwater, wetlands, and inland waters | Tsui |
| Week 3 | Carbon cycling in forests and inland waters | Tsui |
| Week 4 | Nutrient cycling in forests and inland waters | Tsui |
| Week 5 | Sulphur and mercury cycling in terrestrial and freshwater environment | Tsui |
| Week 6 | Biogeochemistry and its applications to study environmental pollution | Tsui |
| Week 7 | Review and midterm exam | |
| Week 8 | Notions of oceanography | Thibodeau |
| Week 9 | Biogeochemical air-sea interface | Thibodeau |
| Week 10 | Organic matter production, export, remineralization and burial | Thibodeau |
| Week 11 | The oceanic carbon, silicate and calcium carbonate cycles | Thibodeau |
| Week 12 | Linkages between nutrient and oxygen cycles in the oceans | Thibodeau |
| Week 13 | Ocean biogeochemistry and climate | Thibodeau |

courses.description: This course aims to provide students with a basic understanding of the operational principles and applications of various instrumental techniques commonly used for the studies of air and water pollution. It is designed to cover atomic and molecular absorption and emission spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, gas chromatography, high-performance liquid chromatography, and electrochemical methods. Emphasis will be placed on the application of such techniques for pollution monitoring and preventive detection systems, especially with reference to the identification and determination of trace levels of toxic heavy metals, organic and organometallic compounds.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CHEM2400 or CHEM3410 or ENSC3415. Pre-requisite: EESC2515 or ENSC2515.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To allow students to gain fundamental knowledge of the principles of instrumental techniques.
2. To allow students to gain fundamental knowledge of mathematical techniques required in treatment of analytical data.
3. To allow students to gain the ability of recognizing key factors and applying appropriate assumption to formulate solutions for environmental analysis.
4. To allow students to acquire problem solving skills including ability to identify key issues and formulate feasible solutions of problems based on logical analysis and critical thinking.
5. To develop students' critical evaluation of issues based on evidence and scientific logic.
6. To allow students to gain ability of analyzing issues quantitatively with the sense of level of uncertainty and reliability.
7. To enhance students' awareness of impacts of instrumental analysis in environmental, social, economic, industrial, and technological aspects.
8. To enhance students' confidence in ability of solving problems.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course will be divided into the following parts:

1. Treatment of Analytical Data
2. Spectroscopic Techniques (UV-VIS, IR, AAS, ICP, MS and XRF)
3. Electrochemical Methods (Potentiometry, Coulometry and Voltammetry)
4. Chromatographic Techniques (GC and HPLC)
5. Environmental Sampling and Analysis

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Environmental Microbiology

meetings.instructor: Dr. ZHANG Li
Dr. ZHANG Li

courses.description: Environmental Microbiology is an interdisciplinary course that explores the fascinating world of microorganisms and their impact on the environment. This comprehensive course covers both the scientific fundamentals and practical applications in the field of Environmental Microbiology. This course will begin with an introduction to the field by covering topics such as the formation of the biosphere, and the science of cell biology. Then the course goes beyond theory and delves into the methods used in environmental microbiology to study microorganisms in their natural habitats. They will also examine the applications of environmental microbiology, such as studying the role of bacteria in climate change, biodegradation, and bioremediation. These practical applications highlight how microorganisms can be harnessed to address environmental challenges and contribute to a sustainable future.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: LSCI1002 or LSCI1012 or EESC2270, or permission of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students would be able to:

1. Demonstrate knowledge of the formation of the biosphere and the role of microorganisms in shaping ecosystems.
2. Describe the basic cellular structures, metabolic processes, and adaptation strategies of microorganisms in various environments in scientific terms.
3. Recognize appropriate methods and techniques for studying microorganisms in their natural habitats, including sample collection, isolation, and community analysis.
4. Evaluate the application of biodegradation, bioremediation technologies and microbial consortia in environmental cleanup and restoration.
5. Apply knowledge and practical insights from environmental microbiology to address real-world environmental challenges and contribute to sustainability efforts.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Introduction to Environmental Microbiology
* Formation of the Biosphere
* Microorganisms: Cell Biology
* Microorganisms: Nutrition and Growth
* Microorganisms: Microbial Diversity
* Methods in Environmental Microbiology
* Microbial Habitats: Soil and Water
* Microbial Habitats: Life in extreme environments
* Application: Bacteria and climate change
* Application: Biodegradation
* Application: Bioremediation

courses.title: Ecotoxicology and Environmental Management

meetings.instructor: Dr. LAU Yee Wai
Dr. LAU Yee Wai

courses.description:
The course introduces various types of chemical contaminants and their adverse effects on animals, humans and ecosystems, and environmental management strategies. It provides an overview of ecotoxicology principles, sources, chemical nature, fate of contaminants, and their interaction and impacts with the ecosystem, and the living organisms in the environment. It also relates ecotoxicology to risk assessment including assessment, monitoring, management and protection of the environment from toxicants.

Students will gain insights into the impacts of pollutants on aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems. They will also delve into sustainable environmental management strategies, including pollution prevention, remediation, and ecological risk assessments.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC3520. Pre-requisite: EESC2515 and LSCI1002, or permission of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Explain the major concepts in ecotoxicology study, including hazard identification, exposure assessment, dose-response assessment.
2. Discuss the attributes, characteristics, and fate of major classes of toxicants.
3. Interpret the mechanisms of interaction and impacts of toxicants at multiple levels of the ecosystem.
4. Analyze environmental toxicants in ecotoxicology research.
5. Assess and evaluate environmental risks associated with toxicants.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Approaches and Methods

1. General Principle of Ecotoxicology 1,5,6,7
2. Contaminant Uptake and Bioaccumulation1,6,7
3. Detection Methods: Analytical and Bioassay 1,3,7
4. Ecotoxicological Studies Models 2,3

Part II: Toxicity of individual substances

5. Heavy Metals 1,5,7
6. Organic Compounds 1.7
7. Pesticides 1,4,5,6
8. Ionizing Radiation1,4,7
9. Natural Toxins 1

Part III: Environmental Management

10. Environmental Epidemiology 1
11. Regulatory Ecological Risk Assessment 1,6,7,8
12. Recovery of Contaminated Sites 7

Part 3: To perform DNA damage analysis of comet assay.

courses.description:

courses.description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the principles and practices of environmental quality monitoring and analysis. Students will develop a solid understanding of the key parameters that affect air, water, and soil quality, learn various monitoring and sampling techniques, and analyze environmental quality conditions and trends. The course will cover theoretical concepts as well as practical application to real-world environmental management scenarios.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: (CHEM1070 or CHEM1072) or (EESC2515 or ENSC2515) or permission of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

1. Identify and describe the major environmental parameters and pollutants that impact environmental quality.
2. Explain the regulatory frameworks and standards related to environmental quality monitoring and compliance.
3. Demonstrate proficiency in sampling techniques and laboratory analysis methods for environmental quality monitoring.
4. Analyze and interpret environmental quality data using statistical and graphical tools.
5. Evaluate the effectiveness of environmental management strategies based on monitoring and analysis results.
courses.course_syllabus:
Module 1: Introduction to Environmental Quality Monitoring

* Overview of environmental quality monitoring and its significance in environmental management
* Introduction to key environmental parameters and pollutants

Module 2: Air Quality Monitoring and Analysis

* Sampling techniques and analysis methods for air quality monitoring
* Interpretation of air quality data and identification of pollutants

Module 3: Water Quality Monitoring and Analysis

* Sampling techniques and analysis methods for water quality monitoring
* Evaluation of water quality parameters and their impact on ecosystems and human health

Module 4: Soil Quality Monitoring and Analysis

* Sampling techniques and analysis methods for soil quality monitoring
* Assessment of soil contamination and its implications for environmental sustainability

Module 5: Environmental Quality Data Visualization and Analysis (Using R)

* Statistical analysis of water quality data
* Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
* Regression analysis
* Trend analysis and Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA)
* Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
* Interpretation of data for decision-making

Module 6: Environmental Management and Compliance

* Evaluation of environmental management strategies based on monitoring and analysis results
* Understanding regulatory frameworks and standards for environmental quality monitoring

courses.description: This course introduces the physical, chemical and biological principles governing the functioning of terrestrial and marine ecosystems, and their roles in shaping the Earth’s climatic and geological environments. Topics include: basic hydrology and surface energy balance; energy, momentum, water and chemical exchange between ecosystems and the atmosphere; cycling of water, carbon and other nutrients in soil, vegetation and ocean; survival strategies of different life forms (especially plants and microorganisms); ecosystem structures and functions; landscapes, disturbances and ecosystem dynamics; human perturbations of biogeochemical cycles via pollution, greenhouse gas emissions and land use; responses and evolution of terrestrial and marine ecosystems under global climate change. This course serves as a comprehensive introduction to ecological climatology, biogeochemistry and ecosystem ecology, and requires basic mathematical operations. This version of the course includes an integrated set of computer laboratory sessions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC3600 or EESC3601 or ESSC3601. Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020 or permission of instructor.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Topic 1: Ecosystems, global plant biogeography and climate
* Topic 2: Plant ecophysiology: photosynthesis and transpiration
* Topic 3: Surface energy balance and biogeophysical climate-vegetation interactions
* Topic 4: Soil and plant biogeochemistry
* Topic 5: Global carbon cycle and biogeochemical feedbacks
* Topic 6: Marine and wetland ecosystems and biogeochemistry
* Topic 7: Nitrogen, aerosols and atmospheric chemistry
* Topic 8: Sustainable ecosystem management

1. Course evaluation – course questionnaire to be answered by all students at the end of the course.
2. Discussion with students – views and suggestions will be gathered regularly from students during tutorials.
3. Reflection of teacher.

2. Schlesinger, W.H., Bernhardt, E.S. (2013): Biogeochemistry: An Analysis of Global Change (3rd edition). Academic Press.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Schimel, D. (2013): Climate and Ecosystems. Princeton University Press.
2. Chapin (III), F.S., Matson, P.A., Vitousek, P.M. (2012): Principles of Terrestrial Ecosystem Ecology (2nd edition). Springer.
3. Valiela, I. (2016): Marine Ecological Processes (3rd edition). Springer.

courses.description:
This course includes the science behind the global warming issue, how the public views the issue and the critical thinking needed to analyze the evidence seen in the media/articles from the point of view of scientists. The world energy use, which is considered to be the cause of global warming, and the impacts are discussed in the course. In this course, students will learn about the radiation budgets/balance in the atmosphere, possible climate forcings that can upset the energy balance, how the earth’s global average temperature is measured, why global warming is described as “the biggest hoax” in human history, observations from the ocean and cryosphere and popular environmental issues/arguments discussed in the mainstream media. Newest observations from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report are included throughout the course.

This course actively incorporates elements of innovation, design, global citizenship and social enterprisingness by asking the students to think innovatively but critically about possible solutions to adapt to and combat climate change and the global energy/health crisis. Different options including their pros and cons are actively discussed in class. Students are encouraged to think creatively about the problem from different angles, e.g., by standing in the shoes of climate skeptics – evaluating their “data”, how they present them, the arguments put forth by them – in order to develop a strategic approach to best communicate the issues to a variety of stakeholders. Project assignments will allow students to focus on one particular environmental issue in other part of the world, attempting to address the issue in the very different geographical, cultural, economic and political contexts from that of the students. Example projects can be “How to use geoengineering to combat climate change?”, “How can Sub-Saharan Africa secure its future food supply under the threat of climate change?”, etc. In the course, students will define and understand the problem. They shall form groups and discuss their own point of views and search information on the evidence of the corresponding arguments. They will present their ideas in class and write a self-reflection report. Each of the group will have to make an “infographic”- a layout of science knowledge learnt in the project that is easy enough for the public to understand but at the same time informative. Good infographics will be used in our OpenDay.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC3800.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, the students will be able to

1. gain understanding of basic climate science behind the global warming issue, including how Earth’s global temperature has been measured by scientists and how the global average temperature is calculated
2. study observations from different components of Earth besides the atmosphere, such as ocean and cryosphere observations, and how these components are affected by the human activities
3. study how the scientific problem is presented and perceived in the society and learn how to use one’s scientific knowledge to identify possible solutions

The active incorporation of elements of innovation and design in the course is critical in allowing the students to develop a keen scientific mindset and logic flow to understand the complexity of the climate change and energy issues (Learning Outcome #1), and to dissect the reasons behind contradictory arguments in a society (Learning Outcome #3). Critical evaluation of the arguments from both sides (climate alarmists vs. skeptics) will ultimately allow them to develop their own stance in the issue, and think critically about the ways to move the world forward towards sustainability (Learning Outcome #3).

The incorporation of global citizenship and social enterprisingness is also crucial for students to develop a keen awareness of how environmental issues affect people in a huge variety of geographical and cultural contexts (Learning Outcome #2), and think critically about what kinds of solutions best fit a certain region (Learning Outcome #3).
courses.course_syllabus:
* L01 Changing Planet (2 lecture-hours)
* L02 Basic Climate Science (2 lecture-hours)
* L03 Energy and Heat (2 lecture-hours)
* L04 Fossil Energy: Coal, Oil, and Natural Gases (2 lecture-hours)
* L05 Impacts of Fossil Fuels (2 lecture-hours)
* L06 Nuclear Energy: an Optimistic Beginning, a Clouded Future (2 lecture-hours)
* Documentary Quiz: Pandora Promise (1.5 hour of video quiz)
* L07 Energy from the Wind and the Sun (2 lecture-hours)
* L08 Air Pollution and Climate Change (2 lecture-hours)
* Documentary: Minimalism (1.5 hour of video)
* L09 Reactive Nitrogen and Climate Change (2 lecture-hours)
* L10 Heatwaves and Climate Change (2 lecture-hours)
* Documentary Quiz: Merchants of Doubt (1.5 hour of video quiz)
* L11 Open Fires and Climate Change (2 lecture-hours)
* L12 Droughts and Climate Change (2 lecture-hours)
* Documentary: Mission Blue (1.5 hour of video)
* L13 Cryosphere and Climate Change (2 lecture-hours)
* Documentary: Chasing Ice (1.5 hour of video)
* L14 Ocean and Climate Change (2 lecture-hours)
* L15 Vision for a low-carbon-energy future (2 lecture-hours)
