courses.description:
This course aims to provide a comprehensive foundation and holistic view on corporate sustainability and the essential skills needed to become a Certified ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) Planner. Students will explore various aspects of sustainability, ESG practices, CEPAR approach and their integration into corporate strategies for long-term value creation.

Students who have successfully completed this course are eligible to apply for membership of International Chamber of Sustainable Development (ICSD) and gain the authorization to use the trademark designation: Certified ESG Planner CEP® (optional and annual fee applies)

Details: https://www.icsd-global.org/certified-esg-planner
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Define the principles and practices of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), corporate sustainability and ESG.
* Describe the history, benefits, and mandatory requirements of ESG reporting.
* Relate green finance and Fintech to corporate sustainability with consideration on corporate strategy and competitiveness.
* Discuss the CEPAR five-step approach and its application in ESG integration investment analysis approach.
* Evaluate and analyze material ESG and sustainability issues among companies.
courses.course_syllabus:
Module 1: Corporate Sustainability Foundation (Sessions 1 to 2)

* Corporate sustainability defined and the basics of sustainability
* Introduction to green finance
* CEPAR five-step approach
* Current practices of ESG and future trend

Module 2: ESG Reporting (Sessions 2 to 3)

* Brief history and benefits of ESG reporting
* Mandatory requirements of ESG reporting
* Case study

Module 3: Sustainable business model & long-term value creation (Sessions 4 to 5)

* Explain why and how companies should connect sustainability to their business model
* Explain how companies should connect sustainability to their competitive position
* intangible assets, and corporate strategy

Module 4: ESG Investment and CEPAR (Sessions 5 to 6)

* Type and history of sustainable and responsible investment: mutual funds
* green bonds, green loans
* ESG indexes and scores
* Performance of sustainable and responsible mutual funds and selecting the funds
* Introduction to ESG integration investment analysis approach
* CEPAR in details

Module 5: Introduction to Information Technology and Fintech Application to Sustainable Development (Session 7)

* Fintech & benefits to sustainable finance
* Sustainable development applications in banking/ insurance/ investing

courses.description: This course presents the fundamentals of continuum mechanics illustrated with earth and environmental sciences applications. Background materials on matrices, vectors and differential operators are first reviewed. The following topics will be covered: tensors and their properties; stress and strain; constitutive equations for Hookean elastic solid and Newtonian viscous fluid; mechanical properties and rheology of geomaterials; Eulerian and Lagrangian kinematics; momentum equations; vorticity and divergence; applications in geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC3010 or 4010.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will acquire systematic training in continuum mechanics, a body of knowledge in mathematics and physics which is of critical importance in a diversity of earth system science applications, including geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography. The mathematical concepts are illustrated with geophysical examples. Students will be well equipped with useful background to pursue more advanced courses on physical aspects of earth system science.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics
Vectors. Cartesian coordinates. Vector algebra.
Determinants. Change of orthonormal basis.
Tensors. Principal values and principal directions
Traction and stress tensor. Principal stresses.
Mohr’s circle.
Current and reference configurations. Strain tensor.
Infinitesimal strain tensor. Rigid body rotation.
Transformation of integrals. Velocity gradient, strain rate and vorticity.
Conservation of mass. Conservation of momentum. Conservation of energy. Ideal constitutive relations: inviscid fluid. Bernoulli’s equation. Potential flow. Ideal constitutive relations: viscous fluid. Steady and non-steady flow.
Ideal constitutive relations: linear solid.
Elastic waves and elasostatics.

courses.title: Soil Mechanics and Its Applications
courses.description: A survey of basic concepts of soil mechanics: Classification and physical properties of soil; stress and strain; pore pressure, seepage theory and effective stress; elastic solutions; shear strength and Mohr-Coulomb theory; failure mode and criteria; soil consolidation; lateral earth pressure; slope stability; bearing capacity and foundation designs; pile analyses and designs; soil improvement and soil nailing. Geotechnical applications: shallow and deep foundations; retaining structures; slope instability.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4020. Pre-requisite: [(MATH1010 or 1030 or 1510 or 1520) or (PHYS1001 or 1002 or 1111 or 1113)] and (EESC2010 or ESSC2010), or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. An understanding of the basics of poromechanics: stress and strain, pore pressure and effective stress, shear strength and failure criteria.
2. Knowledge of the classification and physical properties of soil.
3. A basic understanding of the mechanics of soil, soil consolidation and shear failure.
4. An appreciation of the application of soil mechanics to geotechnical designs and engineering.
courses.course_syllabus:
* A survey of basic concepts of soil mechanics: Classification and physical properties of soil. Physical properties of soil.
* Seepage and effective stress, Pore pressure.
* Stress and strain. Shear strength.
* Soil consolidation. Geotechnical applications: shallow and deep foundations; retaining structures; slope instability.
* Laboratory measurement of soil deformation and strength.

courses.description:
To introduce ground investigation application and practice for urban development as well as field skill performed by the practicing engineering geologists. A review of selected case histories will be provided to illustrate the use of these concepts and skills.
Topics include the factors controlling site selection for a development, desk study and walkover survey, the use of aerial photographic interpretation, ground investigation technology and awareness of site safety, brief introduction of common field and laboratory test methods for soil and rock, introduction of soil and rock description and classification, borehole logging techniques of soil samples and rock types. The content of the course also touches on the basic knowledge of design, management practice of GI works and different roles and responsibilities of GI project personnel.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4030. Pre-requisite: [(EESC2130 or ESSC2130) or (EESC3100 or ESSC3100) or (EESC3110 or ESSC3110) or (EESC4020 or ESSC4020)] and EESC4040, or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. An understanding of the related concepts in engineering geology.
2. Capable to provide description and classification of rock and soil for engineering purposes and hence compile ground investigation report.
3. Understanding basic knowledge of ground investigation works together with some government requirements that are required to follow.
4. Cases studies of engineering geology of selected projects applied to geotechnical problems; critical review of the site investigation, field information etc. will be introduced. Students will be able to carry out independent design of GI works, i.e. feasibility study and selection of site for development, and design of GI stages.
5. Brief understanding to contract management for GI works.
6. Able to work independently as engineering geologists / geologists with minimal subsequent training in the engineering field.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *A**) General Practice of Ground Investigation Works in Hong Kong

1. Purpose of ground investigation.

2. Soil & rock sampling methods and common drilling equipment.

3. Safety and supervision w.r.t. concurrent requirements of the Government.

4. Attention to supervision in drilling.

5. Common field & laboratory tests.

6. Site safety and potential site accidents related to GI works.

* *B) Design for GI Works and Geological Model Construction**

1. Design for GI works (selection of suitable sites for development; siting for GI works for different stages and problem solving of unidentified circumstances in sites with difficult ground conditions during drilling works; no. of drill rigs required; general depth of drilling at particular sites; duration of drilling works for each operation; termination criteria of boreholes for rock types with different geology etc.).
2. Description of rocks and soils (borehole logging)

courses.description: This course introduces concepts, principles, and applications of geophysical methods in environmental and engineering studies. It offers an overall survey of various geophysical methods for exploring the shallow subsurface. It provides the technical foundation needed to understand the use and limitations of gravity, seismic, ground penetrating radar, and electromagnetic methods. Demonstration of commonly used methods will be provided in the field along with tutorials of preliminary data analysis techniques.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4110. Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) and (EESC3120 or ESSC3120).
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Students will become familiar with applied geophysics methods, their principles, and their typical applications
* Students will gains a solid understanding of physical properties of soil and rocks determining geophysical properties
* Students will design and conduct geophysics field surveys, process, analyze, and interpret survey data using computer software
* Students will understand the advantages and limitations of geophysical methods when applied to environmental and engineering studies.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 Introduction to Applied Geophysics. Applications in Hong Kong
Week 2 Gravity Methods
Week 3 Geomagnetic Methods
Week 4 Introduction to seismic methods. Review of seismic waves
Week 5 Seismic refraction
Week 6 Seismic reflection
Week 7 Ground penetrating radar: theory
Week 8 Ground penetrating radar: field procedure and considerations
Week 9 Lab: GPR instrument, common offset survey
Week 10 Lab: GPR: common-mid point survey, Processing GPR CMP data
Week 12 Time-domain EM
Week 13 Nuclear Magnetic Resonance
Week 14 Guest lecture on applied geophysics in Hong Kong

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Advanced Geosciences Field Study I
courses.description: Understanding Earth processes and environmental changes over geological time requires the experience and skills gained from fieldwork. EESC4119 is an advanced-level course of the Earth and Environmental Sciences Programme. It covers important aspects of field geology, including petrology, structural geology, tectonics, geophysics, and surficial processes. The principal goal of this course is to train students to recognize different lithological units and their spatial relationship in three dimensions, and to understand the related tectonic environment and formation mechanisms. Class lectures introduce basic skills of reading and interpreting geological maps, using geological equipment (i.e., compass-clinometer, GPS receiver), and producing field notes and reports. Field projects include field observation and description, techniques for field data acquisition and analysis, sample collection, and geological map compilation. Field projects also focus on surficial processes, which occur over relatively short geological timescales but play important roles in environment and ecology. The field location, whether in mainland China or overseas, may change from year to year.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken EESC3110 or ESSC3110. Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) and [(EESC3100 or ESSC3100) or (EESC4120 or ESSC4120)], or by instructor’s approval.
courses.component:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:

1. Gaining the basic skills of field work in geosciences.
2. Recognizing different lithological units in the field, including sedimentary, metamorphic, volcanic and plutonic complexes.
3. Measuring the geometry of different geological structures in variable scales.
4. Knowing how to use field equipment, such as GPS receivers and Compass-clinometer.
5. Being familiar with the techniques of field data acquisition and analysis.
6. Understanding the standards of sample collection and description.
7. Being able to make field reports and compile a simple geological map.
8. Gaining the capabilities of individual or team-oriented geological field work.

The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 3-4 pre-field lectures/tutorials for introducing geological background of the studied field area.
2. 10-12 days of field study and laboratory visit.
3. Individual field notes and reports are required.

* **Note:*** *Contents may vary depending on some conditions such as weather and safely.*

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Petrology
courses.description: Petrology is an essential subfield of Earth and Environmental Sciences because the rock record is the foundation for interpreting Earth history and internal processes. Petrologic concepts help us understand the Earth system, with connections to related fields such as geochemistry, geophysics, mineralogy, structural geology and geodynamics. This course broadly surveys the formation, distribution, chemical composition, mineral associations, and internal texture and structures in rocks of the earth’s crust and upper mantle, and establishes it relation to global tectonic environments. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise, demonstrations and tutorials (e.g. study of rock hand specimens, understand phase rule, use of optical microscope etc.).
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4120. Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:

1. Gain the skills to identify different rock types (igneous and metamorphic basically).
2. Good knowledge of typical mineral assemblages of different rocks.
3. Use optical polarizing microscope to distinguish: (1) different minerals based on their optical properties, (2) typical igneous and metamorphic micro-textures and structures, (3) featured mineral assemblages corresponding to different P-T conditions.
4. Understand phase equilibrium and phase rule and their applications in understanding the rock forming process.
5. Understand different metamorphic facies and their significance of variable tectonic settings.
6. Use petrologic concepts and theories to address topics of societal interests, including natural hazards, natural resources, and human health issues.

The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Introduction and practice of Electronic Microscope for Petrologic Study
* Phase Rule
* Igneous Petrology
* Sedimentary Petrology
* Metamorphic Petrology

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Advanced Geosciences Field Study II
courses.description: EESC4129 is a comprehensive course designed to provide students with a deep understanding of plate tectonics, advanced geological field techniques, and their applications in engineering and water resources. The course aims to introduce students to the fundamental concepts of plate tectonics, including sea floor spreading, subduction, and mineral deposits. Additionally, it focuses on teaching students advanced geological field techniques and their practical application in field studies. The course also addresses engineering problems related to geological factors and explores the significance of water resources within a geological context. EESC4129 incorporates a combination of theoretical knowledge and practical training. The course includes 10 lectures covering essential concepts and techniques, plus 14 days in the field and engage in onsite discussions. Students will have the opportunity to visit a geologically significant area to gain firsthand experience and understanding of the geological setting, formation processes, tectonic history, and their relationship with urban planning. This field study will provide students with a solid background in local geology and geomorphology, enabling them to comprehend the geological processes and their implications in various settings. Students will engage in a mapping exercise, where they will collect geological data, perform detailed field observations, and analyze their findings. This exercise will enhance their critical thinking skills and equip them with the ability to plan geological projects effectively. Additionally, students will receive training in life-saving skills to ensure their safety during fieldwork. By the end of the course, students will have developed a heightened awareness of the interplay between geology and urban planning, contributing to their holistic understanding of the natural environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) or (EESC2119 or EESC2129) or EESC2160 or (EESC3100 or ESSC3100) or EESC3140 or (EESC4120 or ESSC4120) or with course coordinator’s approval
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:

* Understanding concepts of plate tectonics including sea floor spreading, subduction, and mineral deposits
* Being able to apply the advanced geological field techniques, including identifying mineral assemblages, rock units and outline the key geological and environmental features in the field
* Being able to discuss and apply the geological and environmental concepts to study the engineering problems, water resources and urban planning
* Discussing and analysing the field observation critically based on evidence and scientific principle
* Summarizing information in a clear, concise and logical manner in the field notes, field exercises and group reports to understand geologic processes, tectonic setting and present landform
* Working independently and self-study
* Working in a team and discuss with teammates.
courses.course_syllabus:
10 Pre-trip lectures & Practical sessions:

* General Introduction of tectonic setting and geochemical concepts
* Introduction of local geology of the study area
* Studying typical rock samples and discuss potential research topics
* Field techniques and practice
* Field safety

14-day Field study:

* 8 guided field studies to study geologically significant sites (e.g. ultramafic-mafic rocks of sea floor, mining sites) + on site discussion
* Guided mapping exercises of geological features
* Field visits and discussion on environmental and engineering issues
* Group discussion and presentation of the learning outcomes

Note:

The content may vary depends on the field safety and availability.

courses.description:
This course is an important part of the core Earth and Environmental Sciences Curriculum. It introduces the main concepts in geomorphology with emphasis on understanding the coupling of environments, processes and materials that leads to landform development. Understanding the underlying geological principles of rocks, minerals, structural deformation and geological time are important background knowledge to be enhanced by the study of geomorphology.
It discusses the qualitative and quantitative techniques for investigation and research in the field, laboratory, and computer simulation. The application of geomorphology for public safety, engineering problems and development of sustainable solutions will be emphasized. Examples from theory and practice of geomorphology in Hong Kong will be introduced. Practical understanding and skills will be gained from lab exercises and field trips in Hong Kong.
Students are suggested to be equipped with basic knowledge of rocks and minerals, structural geology and geological time scale.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Seismology
courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of elastic wave propagation and physics of earthquake. The topics covered include the Earth’s internal structure, material elasticity, travel time tomography, seismic ray theory, ray tracing, and earthquake source parameter. Methods and field practice of seismological survey will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4140. Pre-requisite: (EESC3120 or ESSC3120) or ESSC3010.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to know about Earth’s inner structure, understand principles of elastic wave propagation and earthquake physics, seismic imaging, as well as seismic exploration. The students will also be trained with extensive computing exercises. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction

* Overview of seismology
* Scalar wave equation and solutions
* Wave reflection and transmission; propagating and standing waves

Stress and Strain

* Stress tensor
* Eigenvalue and eigenvectors
* Equation of motion
* Strain and rotation
* Elasticity and constitutive law

Wave propagation

* Plane waves
* Geometrical spreading
* Wave propagation in layered medium
* Body waves
* Post-critical reflection and surface waves
* Rayleigh and Love waves

Earthquake source kinematics

* Moment tensor solution
* Isotropic and CLVD components
* Stress drop

Earthquake rupture dynamics

* Friction law
* Coseismic process and earthquake cycles

* Compulsory field trip (subject to available financial support):

Xinfengjiang water reservoir (understanding basics and operation of earthquake engineering for a large facility, specified designs to reduce earthquake shaking, deploying seismic instruments; 8 hours)

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Volcanoes
courses.description: On any given day, ~20 subaerial volcanoes worldwide are erupting. Even more submarine volcanoes are probably erupting without being detected. Volcanic eruptions can have devastating economic and social consequences, but are also the fundamental force that builds the majority of our planet’s surface. Volcanic eruptions and emissions can also affect atmospheric and climate conditions. This course will explore the various techniques used to study volcanoes’ underlying structure as well as their precursory and eruptive activity.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will understand fundamental concepts related to volcanic systems as well as the various techniques used to monitor and study volcanoes. The students will also be trained to read scientific literature, learn new knowledge from them, and synthesize with existing knowledge. Finally, students will learn how to present scientific information in a clear, succinct, and logical manner in both oral and written form as well as in scientific discourse/debate.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Overview of Magmatism and Volcanism
* Magma storage and movement
* Eruption precursors
+ Seismic
+ Geodetic + remote sensing
+ Geochemistry
* Eruption sizes and styles
* Volcanic hazards and risks
* Environmental impacts
* Large igneous provinces
* Submarine volcanism

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Marine Geology and Geophysics
courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of marine geology and geophysics. Marine geology is distinct from that of continent and is the important foundation to launch Plate Tectonics, the modern unified theory of the Earth. In this course, major components of marine geological settings such as mid-ocean ridges, transform faults, subduction zones, oceanic lithosphere, and etc. will be introduced and discussed in details. Methods of geophysical survey will also be introduced. Field experiments of scientific instruments such as Ocean Bottom Seismometers, marine magnetometer and gravimeter will be conducted. A geological field trip will also be included. This course will be jointly offered with Ocean College, Zhejiang University, as an initiative to develop ocean sciences at CUHK.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4160. Pre-requisite: (EESC3120 or ESSC3120) or ESSC3010 or (EESC4010 or ESSC4010).
courses.component:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to know about Earth’s inner structure, and understand principles of marine geology, marine geophysical methods, as well as theory and application of scientific geophysical instruments. Students will also be trained with extensive computing exercises. The students will develop: 1) the ability to solve scientific issues critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work efficiently in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Introduction of regional geology of SE Asia
* Introduction of geology of Zhairuoshan Island
* Observational equipment in Marine Geophysics-1
* Observational equipment in Marine Geophysics-2
* Computing in Marine Geophysics (mapping)
* Computing in Marine Geophysics (data processing)
* Field trip-1: geological structures
* Field trip-2: rocks and stratigraphy
* Field trip-3: coastal geology
* Field trip-4: marine equipment: OBS
* Field trip-5: marine magnetometer
* Field trip-6: multibeam bathymetry
* Final project

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Geodynamics
courses.description: What is the mechanism of plate tectonics and a variety of geological phenomena, such as seafloor spreading, mountain building, volcanoes, earthquakes, faulting? Geodynamics is going to answer those questions through observations and models of the large-scale behaviors of the solid Earth. The goal of the course is to develop a thorough understanding of physical processes, such as lithospheric deformation, heat transfer, and mantle flow. Lectures, paper discussions, and tutorials will help you to understand the principle of geodynamics, learn how to develop simple but useful models, and explain how the Earth evolves.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the fundamental geodynamics principles.
2. Know how to find and process geophysical data, such as topography, gravity, and earthquakes.
3. Able to build and solve geodynamic models and use the model results to explain a variety of geological phenomena.
4. Acquire the ability to read and summarize literatures effectively and efficiently.
5. Develop critical thinking on the previous studies.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Overview of Geodynamics
* Plate Tectonics
* Stress & Strain
* Flexure
* Heat Transfer
* Fluid Mechanics
* Mantle Convection
* Rock Rheology & Faulting

* Gabriele Morra. Pythonic Geodynamics: Implementations for Fast Computing. Springer Cham, 227 pp., 2018.

courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of earthquake source physics. The topics covered include seismic instrumentation, geophysical observations of earthquake source processes, kinematic source representation of earthquakes, dynamic rupture propagation of earthquakes, frictional properties of fault zones, and entire earthquake cycle. Methods and field practice of seismological survey will also be introduced.

courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to know about principles of earthquake source process and relevant observational data that can improve our understanding of earthquake source physics and preparation for seismic hazard. The students will also be trained with extensive computing exercises. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

courses.description: This course introduces the physical, chemical and biological processes governing the exchange of energy, momentum, water and other chemical materials between the atmosphere and land surface, including a formal introduction into boundary-layer meteorology. Topics covered include the basic equations and concepts of heat, momentum and mass conservation and transfer at the land-atmosphere interface; soil physics and hydrometeorology; temperature, humidity and wind distribution in the atmospheric boundary layer; theories and observations of turbulence; boundary layer dynamics; biometeorology and ecophysiology of land plants; canopy and ecosystem exchange; and land use change and urbanization. Applications to weather phenomena, air pollution, forestry, agriculture and ecosystem management will be emphasized throughout.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4210. Pre-requisite: (EESC2020 or ESSC2020) or (EESC3200 or ESSC3200) or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to 1) Gain knowledge of physical, chemical and biological processes of land-atmosphere interactions and boundary layer dynamics; and 2) Develop the skill and ability to understand weather and climate variability related to land-atmosphere interactions. (Course Outcomes as related to Programme Learning Outcomes) -- The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Topics**
Introduction to land-atmosphere interactions; soil physics I: soil heat transfer and temperature dynamics
Hydrological cycle; soil physics II: water movement and infiltration; evapotranspiration; water balance
Surface energy fluxes and balance; soil moisture and atmospheric boundary layer
Basic Thermodynamic Relations and Moisture Content in Air
Static Stability & PBL Structure
Viscous Force and Fundamentals of Turbulence
Eddy Flux & Turbulent Kinetic Energy
Basics on Closure Techniques
More on the Surface & Similarity Theory
Aerodynamic conductance; plant biophysics and ecophysiology
Plant canopies; eddy covariance measurements
Urban climatology; air pollution meteorology

courses.description: This course introduces tropical atmospheric circulation and related air-sea coupling at a variety of spatial and temporal scales. The topics covered include the role of the tropics in the global energy and momentum balance, ITCZ, subtropical high, upper-level anticyclones, tropical ocean circulation, tropical weather, climate and atmosphere-ocean interaction phenomena including meso-scale convective systems, tropical waves, the Hadley and the Walker circulation, El Nino-Southern Oscillation, tropical cyclones, Madden Julian Oscillation, and monsoons.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4220. Pre-requisite: EESC3200 or ESSC3200.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to 1) Gain the knowledge of various tropical atmospheric motions, 2) Understand physical processes in the tropical atmosphere; and 3) Apply knowledge to understand tropical climate variability. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Radiative and convection: Radiative Processes in the Tropics, Surface Energy Balance, Top of the Atmosphere Net Radiation Fluxes, Dry and Moist Stability, Moist Convection
* General circulation in the tropics: Observed zonally averaged Tropical circulation, Theory of the Hadley Cell, Zonally asymmetric circulation features, seasonal variations, diurnal cycle, Observed aspects of the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ), ITCZ theory, Gill model, Heat lows, Tropical ocean circulation, ocean waves.
* Monsoons: Deﬁnition, Differential Heating and the Monsoon, Key Elements of the Asian Summer and Winter Monsoon , Onset and Withdrawal, Breaks in the Indian Monsoon
* El Nino and Southern Oscillation (ENSO): Observational aspect, air-sea interaction, Bjerknes feedback, teleconnection, ENSO modeling, Indian Ocean Dipole
* Madden Julian Oscillation (MJO): Observational aspect, Theory of MJO, Westerly wind bursts, Connection with ENSO
* Tropical Waves and Tropical Depressions (TD): Matsuno wave theory, convective coupled equatorial waves, easterly waves and TD-type disturbances, relationship with Tropical Cyclones (TC) genesis
* TC: Structure, Genesis, dynamics of TC movement, and intensiﬁcation, modeling and forecasting
* Tropical Squall Lines and Mesoscale Convective Systems (MCS): Observations of MCS and squall lines, dynamical aspects, Organization of Convection

courses.description: Fundamentals of aerosol physics and chemistry; condensation and evaporation; thermodynamics; nucleation, diffusion, coagulation; radiative, hygroscopic properties, and cloud formation potential of aerosols; aerosol phase oxidation reactions; heterogeneous oxidative processes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4230. Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020 or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Students will learn how various atmospheric physical processes determine the composition and properties of atmospheric aerosols.
* Students will learn how physical chemistry, spectroscopy, kinetics, and thermodynamics govern the chemical processes in atmospheric aerosols.
* Students will learn how atmospheric processes alter the aerosol-cloud formation.
* Students will learn how to use laboratory measurements together with model stimulations to study the physical and chemical processes occurred in the aerosols.
courses.course_syllabus:

Introduction to atmospheric aerosols

Gas-phase chemistry

Dynamics of a single aerosol

Thermodynamics of aerosols (deliquescence and crystallization)

Aerosol-cloud formation: Role of organic compounds

Condensation and evaporation of aerosols

Coagulation

Nucleation

Aerosol measurement techniques

Special topic: Formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA)

Special topic: Heterogeneous oxidation of aerosols

courses.title: Air Pollution Science and Engineering
courses.description: This course will cover a variety of topics related to air pollution science and engineering. Topics include: indoor and outdoor air quality (including particulate matters (PM) and gases pollutants); air pollution measurement and statistics; air quality meteorology and dispersion models; principles and challenges of air pollution control and measurement.

courses.learning_outcomes:
* To understand the physical and chemical principles governing the sources, formation, transport, transformation, health impacts of air pollutants in both indoor and outdoor environments.
* To understand the working principles of various air pollution monitoring instrumentation.
* To apply statistical tools and mathematical models to solve air pollutant dispersion problems.
* To apply various air pollution engineering approaches to solve air pollution issues.
* To gain a better understanding of current air pollution problems and control challenges.

courses.title: General Circulation and Climate Models
courses.description: This course is about the general circulation of the atmosphere, oceans, and the interactions among them and with other components of the Earth System, as well as their simulations using climate models, in the context of climate variability and climate change. Topics include basic fluid dynamics of large-scale atmospheric and oceanic motions, radiative transfer, atmospheric general circulation, midlatitude dynamics, ocean general circulation, and general circulation models.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4250. Pre-requisite: EESC3200 or ESSC3200 or permission of instructor.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction of the large-scale atmosphere and ocean flow and their governing dynamics
2. Radiative transfer and energy balance of the Earth’s climate system
3. Atmospheric general circulation, midlatitude eddies, wave-mean flow interactions, blockings/low-frequency behaviour
4. Ocean general circulation
5. General circulation model development
6. State-of-the-art Earth System models

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Urban Climatology
courses.description: Human modifications to the surface of the Earth during urbanisation change most of the elements of climate and weather in the urban atmosphere. This course introduces the fundamentals of urban climatology and the processes caused by the changes in the surface environment, particularly focusing on how urban structures interact with the atmospheric environment. Numerical modelling and field techniques are introduced to understand the underlying processes resulting urban climatic phenomena. It also examines the implications on human comfort and climate-sensitive urban planning and design, as well as the relationship between cities and climate change
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4260. Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Topic and Content/Fundamental concept**
Week 1 Lecture 1: Introduction to urbanisation and urban climate

Week 2 Lecture 2: Fundamentals of urban climatology I
• Urban boundary layer (UBL) and urban canopy layer (UCL)
• Urban climatic processes within UBL and UCL

Week 3 Lecture 3: Fundamentals of urban climatology II
• Heterogeneity of urban surface environment
• Atmospheric turbulence and exchange of energy and water

Week 4 Lecture 4: Urban energy balance I
• Anthropogenic heat flux
• Urban radiation balance

Week 5 Lecture 5: Urban energy balance II
• Urban canopy energy balance
• Urban neighbourhood energy balance

Week 6 Lab 1: Urban Multi-scale Environmental Predictor (UMEP): An integrated tool for city-based climate services

Week 7 Lecture 6: Urban heat islands – History and physical basis
• Detection of urban heat island: Luke Howard in 1810s
• Determinants of heat island magnitude and structure
• Diversity of urban heat island

Week 8 Lecture 7: Monitoring urban heat islands
• Ground-level meteorological measurements
• Mobile measurements
• Land surface temperature

Week 9 Lecture 8: Urban heat islands – Examples of different climatic regions
• Tropical climates: Singapore and India
• Sub-tropical climates: Hong Kong and South Africa
• Mediterranean climates: Greece and Spain
• High-latitude climates: Sweden and the United Kingdom

Week 10 Lecture 9: Urban climatic mapping
• Urban climatic maps – History, development, and applications
• Local climatic zones – Classification of surface environment

Week 11 Lecture 10: Application of urban climatology in climate-sensitive urban planning and design
• Why urban planning and design matters?
• Air Ventilation Assessment System
• Sustainable Building Design Guidelines

Week 12 Lab 2: Mapping of local climatic zones using WUDAPT methodology

Week 13 Lecture 11: Cities and climate change

courses.description:
This course presents an introduction to the science of clouds. We begin with a descriptive cloud classification to introduce the different types of clouds in the Earth’s atmosphere. The roles of aerosols in cloud are also discussed. This is followed by cloud microphysics, describing the basic microphysical processes regarding formation, growth, shrinkage, breakup and fallout of cloud and precipitation particles. Next, different structures of precipitation and radar cloud sensing are presented. This will then be linked to cloud dynamics, associated with the fluid motions of the atmosphere.

Student taking this course are expected to have taken EESC2020 or ESSC2020.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students shall learn about a wide variety of physics and dynamics that control the occurrence, characteristics, and behavior of clouds. They shall understand the processes determining all the types of clouds in our atmosphere, over a wide range of spatial scales from microns to thousands of kilometers. They shall appreciate the importance of cloud to Earth’s climate. There are also be opportunities (e.g. outdoor cloud observation, cloud dynamics practicals both computationally and experimentally) where student can practice working effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Topics**

* *Topic 1: Cloud Properties**

* *Topic 2: Mixing and Convection in Clouds**

* *Topic 3: Atmospheric Aerosols**

* *Topic 4: Köhler Theory in Cloud Droplet Formation**

Topic 5: Microphysical Processes in Warm Clouds

Topic 6: Microphysical Processes in Cold Clouds

Topic 7: Precipitation

Topic 8: Synoptic and Mesoscale Cloud Dynamics

Practical 1: Cloud Droplet Formation and Dust

Practical 2: Tornado Cloud Dynamics

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Practical Meteorology
courses.description: Practical Meteorology is an advanced undergraduate course designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of various aspects of meteorology and their practical applications. The course will cover synoptic and mesoscale meteorology, satellite and radar meteorology, radiative transfer, lidar meteorology, aviation meteorology, and atmospheric instrumentation. Through a combination of lectures and case studies using instrument data, students will gain hands-on experience in analyzing and interpreting meteorological data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Analyze the concepts of synoptic and mesoscale meteorology and their impact on weather patterns and atmospheric processes.
2. Evaluate the principles and applications of satellite and radar meteorology in predicting weather conditions, detecting severe weather events, and investigating climate patterns.
3. Assess the fundamental principles of radiative transfer and its significance in maintaining energy balance, understanding climate change, and utilizing remote sensing techniques.
4. Examine the principles of lidar meteorology and its practical applications in profiling the atmosphere, studying aerosols, and analyzing the boundary layer.
5. Utilize atmospheric instrumentation data to conduct case studies, perform data analysis, and interpret findings to enhance understanding of meteorological phenomena.
6. Apply critical thinking and problem-solving skills to real-world scenarios by integrating meteorological concepts and theories into practical situations.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to synoptic and mesoscale meteorology:
1. Weather systems and their characteristics
2. Analysis and interpretation of weather maps
3. Atmospheric circulation patterns
4. Frontal systems and their impacts
2. Satellite and radar meteorology:
1. Satellite remote sensing principles and techniques
2. Interpretation of satellite imagery for weather analysis
3. Radar systems and their applications in severe weather detection
4. Doppler radar and its role in analysing storm dynamics
3. Radiative transfer:
1. Solar radiation and its interaction with the atmosphere
2. Greenhouse effect and climate change
3. Remote sensing applications of radiative transfer
4. Lidar meteorology:
1. Principles of lidar remote sensing
2. Lidar applications in atmospheric profiling
3. Aerosol studies using lidar
4. Boundary layer analysis with lidar
5. Aviation meteorology:
1. Meteorological factors affecting aviation operations
2. Weather hazards and their impact on flight safety
3. Aviation weather forecasting techniques
4. Application of meteorological information in flight planning and decision-making
6. Atmospheric instrumentation:
1. Introduction to meteorological instruments
2. Principles of measurement and calibration
3. Analysis and interpretation of instrument data for case studies

courses.description: This course is designed to extend students' understanding of and develop their ability in the application of various aspects of environmental chemistry in relation to the major types of air and water pollution associated with industrial and vehicle emissions. It outlines the basic processes in bleaching and dyeing, electroplating and food processing that give rise to water pollution and application of physico-chemical techniques in controlling such pollution. It also examines combustion processes and the associated applications and limitations of the absorption, adsorption, oxidation-reduction and catalytic conversion techniques in relation to aerial emissions from furnaces and vehicles. Site visits will be arranged where possible to enhance students' ability in application.

courses.learning_outcomes: Students will become familiar with air and water pollution associated with industrial and vehicle emissions. They will be able to evaluate the basic pollution control and prevention approaches in bleaching and dyeing, electroplating and food processing industries.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Biogeochemistry

meetings.instructor:
Dr. ZHANG Li, 
Professor Benoit THIBODEAU

Dr. ZHANG Li, 
Professor Benoit THIBODEAU

Dr. ZHANG Li, 
Professor Benoit THIBODEAU

courses.description: This course presents the recent understanding and advancements in global biogeochemistry. The lectures are on a range of topics, covering major elemental cycles from the early Earth to future projections and from the lithosphere to the atmosphere, with an emphasis on the Ocean. Advanced concepts of application of biogeochemistry will further be discussed with an emphasis on environmental pollution and global climate change. The fundamentals of major elemental cycles like carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, oxygen, sulphur, and silicate will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1) Pre-requisite: EESC/ESSC3020 or EESC/ESSC3220 or EESC3230 or EESC/ESSC3300 or EESC3510 or EESC3520 or EESC/ESSC3600 or EESC/ESSC3800.
2) Not for those taken ENSC/EESC3330. 
3) Need basic knowledge in environmental science and chemistry.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:

1. Understand the key processes regulating elemental cycling in the environment, focusing on oceans.
2. Apply biogeochemistry concepts to global issues like pollution and climate change.
3. Evaluate research on major elemental cycles, including carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, oxygen, sulfur, and silicate.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course explores the latest insights and advancements in global biogeochemistry. It covers a range of topics, including major elemental cycles from early Earth to future projections, spanning the lithosphere to the atmosphere, with a focus on the ocean. Advanced applications in environmental pollution and climate change will be discussed, alongside fundamentals of key cycles like carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, oxygen, sulfur, and silicate.

| Week 1 | Introduction; overview of global environmental problems and key elements; basics of environmental chemistry |
| --- | --- |
| Week 2 | Origins of the elements, life and early biosphere |
| Week 3 | The Atmosphere |
| Week 4 | The Lithosphere |
| Week 5 | Carbon cycle in terrestrial ecosystems |
| Week 6 | Biogeochemical cycles on land (incl. wetlands, inland waters, etc) |
| Week 7 | Review and midterm exam |
| Week 8 | Ocean transport and box modelling |
| Week 9 | Isotopes in biogeochemistry |
| Week 10 | Organic matter production, export and remineralization |
| Week 11 | Nitrogen and phosphorous cycling |
| Week 12 | Linkages between climate and biogeochemistry |
| Week 13 | Student presentations |

courses.description: This course introduces the principles and applications of various chemical and physiochemical processes applicable for treatment and control of air and water pollution. It studies the processes of neutralization, oxidation-reduction, chemical precipitation, coagulation, flocculation, physical separation, absorption, adsorption, filtration, chemical disinfection, solvent extraction, fractional distillation and incineration. It also examines the applicabilities and limitations of such processes with reference to the treatment and recovery of toxic and hazardous chemical wastes. Site visits will be arranged to enhance students' ability in application.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC4535. Pre-requisite: EESC2515 or ENSC2515 or permission of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will become familiar with various chemical and physico-chemical processes applicable for treatment and control of air and water pollution. They will be able to evaluate the applicabilities and limitations of such processes with reference to the treatment and recovery of toxic and hazardous chemical wastes.

courses.description: This course introduces the contemporary problems and issues in environmentally dependent aspects of health. Broad coverage of health effects of foodborne, airborne and waterborne pollutants, pesticides, and consumer product are considered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC4250. Pre-requisite: EESC3520 or ENSC3520.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course is designed to give students an overview of the sources, modes of action, and health effects of the global and local important pollutants including pesticides, food additives, transgenes in genetically modified foods, environmental tobacco smoke, indoor air pollutants, water pollutants, peroxisome proliferators, environmental estrogens, and benzene. After the study, the student should be able to:

1. Describe the sources of the pollutants
2. Understand the modes of action of the pollutants
3. Familiar with the symptoms and human health effects resulting from exposure to the pollutants
4. Discuss ways to reduce our exposure to the pollutants

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Statistical Methods and Data Analysis for Earth and Environmental Sciences
courses.description:
This course covers the theoretical basis and practical applications of data analysis relevant for earth and environmental sciences. This course aims to introduce students to Earth and environmental data manipulation, from sampling, reading and writing, to statistical analysis and parameter estimation, to time series analysis, to plotting and visualization. Topics include: digital signal processing, sampling techniques; probability distributions; hypothesis testing; correlation analysis; linear and nonlinear regression; statistical forecasting, harmonic analysis and spectral analysis; principle component analysis; and geostatistics. Tutorials will be based on real geophysical examples including remote sensing and in situ observations, as well as model data.

Previous elementary coding experience in Python 3 is recommended.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4510. Pre-requisite: (STAT1011 or 1012), and ((EESC2030 or ESSC2030) or PHYS2061).
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will become knowledgeable about the acquisition, pre-processing and analysis of geophysical and environmental data, including remote sensing, in situ observation and model data. Students will acquire knowledge on techniques for data processing, including visualization methods and statistical analysis, and on the applications of these data and tools to geophysical and environmental problems. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principles, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students can also acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Exploratory Data Analysis
* Correlation Analysis
* Parametric Probability Distribution : Discrete
* Parametric Probability Distribution : Continuous
* Hypothesis Testing
* Frequentist Statistical Inference: Resampling Methods
* Statistical Forecasting: Simple Linear Regression
* Statistical Forecasting: Multiple Linear Regression, Non-Linear Regression
* Statistical Forecasting: Predictor Selection, Ensemble Forecasting
* Linear algebra and matrix inverse
* Quantifying preconceptions: Bayesian inference
* Quantifying preconceptions: Prior information
* Detecting periodicities: Sinusoidal functions and Fourier series
* Detecting periodicities: Complex Fourier series and Fourier transform
* The past influences the present: Convolution
* The past influences the present: Filters
* Cross-correlation
* Bandpass filters and windowing
* Filling in missing data
* Approximation
* Principal Component Analysis I
* Time Series Analysis
* Forecast Verification

3. Reflection of teacher

courses.description: Remote sensing observations are critical for monitoring regional and global changes, determining spatial and temporal variability of the Earth System, and addressing fundamental global issues. This course introduces the basic physical principles of remote sensing, including electromagnetic waves and radiation, optical, microwave, and non-imaging remote sensing. It also presents key concepts and examples on remote sensing applications in Earth system science (such as atmosphere, lithosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere) and global changes. This course also provides computer-based lab exercises that facilitate the understanding of remote sensing principles and the processing of remote sensing data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4540. Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) &(EESC2020 or ESSC2020) & (MATH1010 or 1030 or 1510 or 1520) & (PHYS1001 or 1002 or 1111 or 1113) & ((EESC2030 or ESSC2030) or PHYS2061), or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course will contribute to understanding of basic concepts and principles of remote sensing at optical and microwave frequencies from airborne and spaceborne platforms. With the help from laboratory analysis and case studies, remote sensing applications in Earth system science can be further understood.
The students will develop:
1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle,
2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently,
3) to work effectively in a team, and
4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.
The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week Topics

1. Introduction, Remote sensing platforms
2. Electromagnetic waves and radiation, Electromagnetic interaction with matters
3. Radiative Transfer
4. Photogrammetry and stereogrammetry, Structure from Motion
5. Optical sensors
6. Remote Sensing Data Processing I: ENVI, color compositive, band math
7. Passive microwave remote sensing
8. Active remote sensing: Radar ranging
9. Active remote sensing: LiDAR ranging
10. Remote Sensing Data Processing II: data fitting
11. Synthetic Aperture Radar, Interferometric SAR
12. Remote Sensing Data Processing III: image processing, filtering
13. Remote Sensing Data Processing IV: change detection, classification
14. Machine learning and deep learning in remote sensing

courses.description: This course introduces the basic principles of atmospheric modeling and provides hands-on practice to perform numerical simulations on University computing cluster. It begins with the concept of model and reviewing of physical and chemical processes in the atmosphere. After that, this course will cover introduction and hands-on practice of the three basic processes in atmospheric simulation: pre-processing data, modeling, and post-processing data. The pre-processing process refers to the preparation of data from various sources by different techniques such as the generation of emission inventories for atmospheric chemistry modeling. It then introduces numerical modeling basics such as “model equations and numerical approaches”. For post-processing, this course offers different skills in visualization of the model output and evaluation of model output against real-world observations. This course also introduces advanced knowledge in “model coupling” and “inverse modeling”. Finally, this course provides hands-on practice on simple model development experiments. During the course, we will cover basic Linux environment commands to perform the main tasks mentioned above. Overall, students can anticipate grasping basic modeling concepts and skills from this course, which are of great value to their future careers in both academia and industry.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: (EESC2020 or ESSC2020) and (MATH2550 or EESC2520 or PHYS2051) and (PHYS1001 or 1002 or 1111 or 1113), or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Remember and explain the major chemical and physical processes that affect spatiotemporal variations of major atmospheric composition.
2. Explain the basic framework of atmospheric chemistry models including their input and output.
3. Understand what an emission inventory is and be able to pre-process emission inventory for atmospheric chemistry models.
4. Able to compile and run an atmospheric chemistry model.
5. Capable of visualizing model outputs and evaluating model outputs against observations.
6. Have the skills to sort out model structure by reading model codes and then revise model codes according to research needs.
courses.course_syllabus:
* The concept of model
* Processes in the atmosphere I - physical processes
* Processes in the atmosphere II - chemical processes
* Surface fluxes I - emission
* Surface fluxes II - deposition
* Model equations and numerical approaches
* Formulations of radiative, chemical, and aerosol rates
* Parameterization of subgrid-scale processes
* Post-processing model output data
* Model evaluation
* Model coupling
* Inverse modeling
* Model development experiments

* Discussion with students – views and suggestions will be gathered at least two times during the term.
* Reflection of teacher.

Please choose either “documents of the GEOS-Chem model” or “documents of the WRF model” as detailed below -

* Documents of the GEOS-Chem model
+ <https://geoschem.github.io/>
+ https://geos-chem.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

* Documents of the Weather Research & Forecasting Model (WRF) model.
+ https://www.mmm.ucar.edu/models/wrf
+ https://www2.mmm.ucar.edu/wrf/users/docs/user\_guide\_v4/v4.4/contents.html

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Environmental Sciences Field Study II
courses.description:
This course gives students an opportunity to supplement what they have learnt from the major courses in the format of a local or overseas field trip during summer. Students are required to submit a proposal, participate actively in all activities throughout the field trip, submit an individual report and present a seminar for assessment. The field trip must be approved by the Programme.

Students will learn as a global citizen how to learn from other countries’ experiences to act locally in environmental management and protection with innovative ideas and social responsibility.

Students will also learn from social enterprise or non-government organizations how to work together with government officials and regular citizens to enhance conservation and environmental protection.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: (EESC3230 or ENSC3230) or EESC3510 or (EESC3520 or ENSC3520) or EESC3530 or EESC3540 or (EESC4340 or ENSC4240) or (EESC4350 or ENSC4250) or permission of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students taken this course are anticipated to acquire the following abilities:

1. Demonstrate an understanding of sustainability concepts and their application in ecological sites.
2. Apply field research techniques and knowledge learnt previously in data collection and solving problems.
3. Interpret and analyze field data to draw conclusions and make recommendations for sustainable practices.
4. Communicate scientific findings effectively through written reports and oral presentations.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Sustainability and Ecological Sites
2. Field Study Techniques
3. Sustainable Development and Land Use
4. Ecological Restoration and Conservation
5. Sustainable Energy and Resource Management
6. Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services
7. Environmental Policy and Governance
8. Field Study Project and Presentation

* Discussion with students: view and suggestions will be gathered from students.
* Reflection of teacher

courses.description: This course presents the fundamentals of continuum mechanics illustrated with earth system science applications. Background materials on matrices, vectors and differential operators are first reviewed. The following topics will be covered: tensors and their properties; stress and strain; constitutive equations for Hookean elastic solid and Newtonian viscous fluid; mechanical properties and rheology of geomaterials; Eulerian and Lagrangian kinematics; momentum equations; vorticity and divergence; applications in geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion(s): ESSC3010, ESSC4010, EASC5010.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will acquire systematic training in continuum mechanics, a body of knowledge in mathematics and physics which is of critical importance in a diversity of earth system science applications, including geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography. The mathematical concepts are illustrated with geophysical examples. Students will be well equipped with useful background to pursue more advanced courses on physical aspects of earth system science.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics

Vectors. Cartesian coordinates. Vector algebra.

Determinants. Change of orthonormal basis.

Tensors. Principal values and principal directions

Traction and stress tensor. Principal stresses.

Mohr’s circle.

Current and reference configurations. Strain tensor.

Infinitesimal strain tensor. Rigid body rotation.

Transformation of integrals. Velocity gradient, strain rate and vorticity.

Conservation of mass. Conservation of momentum. Conservation of energy. Ideal constitutive relations: inviscid fluid. Bernoulli’s equation. Potential flow. Ideal constitutive relations: viscous fluid. Steady and non-steady flow.

Ideal constitutive relations: linear solid.

Elastic waves and elasostatics.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Soil Mechanics and Its Applications
courses.description: A survey of basic concepts of soil mechanics: Classification and physical properties of soil; stress and strain; pore pressure, seepage theory and effective stress; elastic solutions; shear strength and Mohr-Coulomb theory; failure mode and criteria; soil consolidation; lateral earth pressure; slope stability; bearing capacity and foundation designs; pile analyses and designs; soil improvement and soil nailing. Geotechnical applications: shallow and deep foundations; retaining structures; slope instability.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5020.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. An understanding of the basics of poromechanics: stress and strain, pore pressure and effective stress, shear strength and failure criteria.
2. Knowledge of the classification and physical properties of soil.
3. A basic understanding of the mechanics of soil, soil consolidation and shear failure.
4. An appreciation of the application of soil mechanics to geotechnical designs and engineering.
courses.course_syllabus:
* A survey of basic concepts of soil mechanics: Classification and physical properties of soil. Physical properties of soil.
* Seepage and effective stress, Pore pressure.
* Stress and strain. Shear strength.
* Soil consolidation. Geotechnical applications: shallow and deep foundations; retaining structures; slope instability.
* Laboratory measurement of soil deformation and strength.

PART II. Geophysical applications

Theme 1. Geohazards and mitigation

courses.description: This course is about the general circulations of the atmosphere, ocean, the interactions among them and with other components of the Earth System, as well as their simulations using climate models, in the context of climate variability and climate change. Topics include basic fluid dynamics of large-scale atmosphere and ocean circulations, radiative transfer, atmospheric general circulation, mid latitude dynamics, ocean general circulation, general circulation models, Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change reports.

3. Atmospheric general circulation, mid-latitude eddies, wave-mean flow interaction, blockings/low-frequency behaviour
4. Ocean general circulation
5. General circulation models
6. IPCC reports

courses.description: This course introduces concepts, principles, and applications of geophysical methods in environmental and engineering studies. It offers an overall survey of various geophysical methods for exploring the shallow subsurface. It provides the technical foundation needed to understand the use and limitations of gravity, seismic, ground penetrating radar, and electromagnetic methods. Demonstration of commonly used methods will be provided in the field along with tutorials of preliminary data analysis techniques. Technical papers published in leading applied geophysics journals will be discussed in reading groups.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5110.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Students will become familiar with applied geophysics methods, their principles, and their typical applications
* Students will gain a solid understanding of physical properties of soil and rocks determining geophysical properties
* Students will design and conduct geophysics field surveys, process, analyze, and interpret survey data using computer software
* Students will understand the advantages and limitations of geophysical methods when applied to environmental and engineering studies.
* Students will critically understand and judge technical papers published in leading applied geophysics journals
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Week 1** Introduction to Applied Geophysics. Applications in Hong Kong

* *Week 2** Gravity Methods

* *Week 3** Geomagnetic Methods

* *Week 4** Introduction to seismic methods. Review of seismic waves

* *Week 5** Seismic refraction

* *Week 6** Seismic reflection

* *Week 7** Ground penetrating radar: theory

* *Week 8** Ground penetrating radar: field procedure and considerations

* *Week 9** Lab: GPR instrument, common offset survey

* *Week 10** Lab: GPR: common-mid point survey, Processing GPR CMP data

* *Week 11** Time-domain EM

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Petrology
courses.description: Petrology is an essential subfield of Earth System Science because the rock record is the foundation for interpreting Earth history and internal processes. Petrologic concepts help us understand the Earth system, with connections to related fields such as geochemistry, geophysics, mineralogy, structural geology and geodynamics. This course broadly surveys the formation, distribution, chemical composition, mineral associations, and internal texture and structures in rocks of the earth’s crust and upper mantle, and establishes it relation to global tectonic environments. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise, demonstrations and tutorials (e.g. study of rock hand specimens, understand phase rule, use of optical microscope etc.).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5120.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:

1. Gain the skills to identify different rock types (igneous and metamorphic basically).
2. Good knowledge of typical mineral assemblages of different rocks.
3. Use optical polarizing microscope to distinguish: (1) different minerals based on their optical properties, (2) typical igneous and metamorphic micro-textures and structures, (3) featured mineral assemblages corresponding to different P-T conditions.
4. Understand phase equilibrium and phase rule and their applications in understanding the rock forming process.
5. Understand different metamorphic facies and their significance of variable tectonic settings.
6. Use petrologic concepts and theories to address topics of societal interests, including natural hazards, natural resources, and human health issues.

The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Introduction and practice of Electronic Microscope for Petrologic Study
* Phase Rule
* Igneous Petrology
* Sedimentary Petrology
* Metamorphic Petrology

courses.description:
This course is an important part of the core Earth and Environmental Sciences Curriculum. It introduces the main concepts in geomorphology with emphasis on understanding the coupling of environments, processes and materials that leads to landform development. Understanding the underlying geological principles of rocks, minerals, structural deformation and geological time are important background knowledge to be enhanced by the study of geomorphology.
It discusses the qualitative and quantitative techniques for investigation and research in the field, laboratory, and computer modeling.
The application of geomorphology for public safety, engineering problems and development of sustainable solutions will be emphasized. Examples from theory and practice of geomorphology in Hong Kong will be introduced. Practical understanding and skills will be gained from lab exercises and field trips in Hong Kong.
Students are suggested to be equipped with basic knowledge of rocks and minerals, structural geology and geological time scale.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Seismology
courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of elastic wave propagation and physics of earthquake. The topics covered include the Earth’s internal structure, material elasticity, travel time tomography, seismic ray theory, ray tracing, and earthquake source parameter. Methods and field practice of seismological survey and programming methods of data processing will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5140.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to know about Earth’s inner structure, understand principles of elastic wave propagation and earthquake physics, seismic imaging, as well as seismic exploration. The students will also be trained with extensive computing exercises. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Introduction
+ Overview of seismology
+ Scalar wave equation and solutions
+ Wave reflection and transmission; propagating and standing waves
* Stress and Strain
+ Stress tensor
+ Eigenvalue and eigenvectors
+ Equation of motion
+ Strain and rotation
+ Elasticity and constitutive law
* Wave propagation
+ Plane waves
+ Geometrical spreading
+ Wave propagation in layered medium
+ Body waves
+ Post-critical reflection and surface waves
+ Rayleigh and Love waves
* Earthquake source kinematics
+ Moment tensor solution
+ Isotropic and CLVD components
+ Stress drop
* Earthquake rupture dynamics
+ Friction law
+ Coseismic process and earthquake cycles

* **Compulsory field trip** **(subject to available financial support):**

Xinfengjiang water reservoir (understanding basics and operation of earthquake engineering for a large facility, specified designs to reduce earthquake shaking, deploying seismic instruments; 8 hours)

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Volcanoes
courses.description: On any given day, ~20 subaerial volcanoes worldwide are erupting. Even more submarine volcanoes are probably erupting without being detected. Volcanic eruptions can have devastating economic and social consequences, but are also the fundamental force that builds the majority of our planet’s surface. Volcanic eruptions and emissions can also affect atmospheric and climate conditions. This course will explore the various techniques used to study volcanoes’ underlying structure as well as their precursory and eruptive activity.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5150.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will understand fundamental concepts related to volcanic systems as well as the various techniques used to monitor and study volcanoes. The students will also be trained to read scientific literature, learn new knowledge from them, and synthesize with existing knowledge. Finally, students will learn how to present scientific information in a clear, succinct, and logical manner in both oral and written form as well as in scientific discourse/debate.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Overview of Magmatism and Volcanism
* Magma storage and movement
* Eruption precursors
+ Seismic
+ Geodetic + remote sensing
+ Geochemistry
* Eruption sizes and styles
* Volcanic hazards and risks
* Environmental impacts
* Large igneous provinces
* Submarine volcanism

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Geodynamics
courses.description: What is the mechanism of plate tectonics and a variety of geological phenomena, such as seafloor spreading, mountain building, volcanoes, earthquakes, faulting? Geodynamics is going to answer those questions through observations and models of the large-scale behaviors of the solid Earth. The goal of the course is to develop a thorough understanding of physical processes, such as lithospheric deformation, heat transfer, and mantle flow. Lectures, paper discussions, and tutorials will help you to understand the principle of geodynamics, learn how to develop simple but useful models, and explain how the Earth evolves.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5170.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the fundamental geodynamics principles.
2. Know how to find and process geophysical data, such as topography, gravity, and earthquakes.
3. Able to build and solve geodynamic models and use the model results to explain a variety of geological phenomena.
4. Acquire the ability to read and summarize literatures effectively and efficiently.
5. Develop critical thinking on the previous studies.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Overview of Geodynamics
* Plate Tectonics
* Stress & Strain
* Flexure
* Heat Transfer
* Fluid Mechanics
* Mantle Convection
* Rock Rheology & Faulting
