courses.description: This course introduces the physical, chemical and biological processes governing the exchange of energy, momentum, water and other chemical materials between the atmosphere and land surface, including a formal introduction into boundary-layer meteorology. Topics covered include the basic equations and concepts of heat, momentum and mass conservation and transfer at the land-atmosphere interface; soil physics and hydrometeorology; temperature, humidity and wind distribution in the atmospheric boundary layer; theories and observations of turbulence; stability and boundary-layer dynamics; biometeorology and ecophysiology of land plants; canopy and ecosystem exchange; and land use change and urbanization. Applications to weather phenomena, air pollution, forestry, agriculture and ecosystem management will be emphasized throughout.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5210.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to 1) Gain knowledge of physical, chemical and biological processes of land-atmosphere interactions and boundary layer dynamics; and 2) Develop the skill and ability to understand weather and climate variability related to land-atmosphere interactions. (Course Outcomes as related to Programme Learning Outcomes) -- The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Topics**

Introduction to land-atmosphere interactions; soil physics I: soil heat transfer and temperature dynamics

Hydrological cycle; soil physics II: water movement and infiltration; evapotranspiration; water balance

Surface energy fluxes and balance; soil moisture and atmospheric boundary layer

Basic Thermodynamic Relations and Moisture Content in Air

Static Stability & PBL Structure

Viscous Force and Fundamentals of Turbulence

Eddy Flux & Turbulent Kinetic Energy

Basics on Closure Techniques

More on the Surface & Similarity Theory

Aerodynamic conductance; plant biophysics and ecophysiology

Plant canopies; eddy covariance measurements

Urban climatology; air pollution meteorology

courses.description: This course introduces tropical atmospheric circulation and related air-sea coupling at a variety of spatial and temporal scales. The topics covered include the role of the tropics in the global energy and momentum balance, ITCZ, subtropical high, upper-level anticyclones, tropical ocean circulation, tropical weather, climate and atmosphere-ocean interaction phenomena including meso-scale convective systems, tropical waves, the Hadley and the Walker circulation, El Nino-Southern Oscillation, tropical cyclones, Madden Julian Oscillation, and monsoons.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5220.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to 1) Gain the knowledge of various tropical atmospheric motions, 2) Understand physical processes in the tropical atmosphere; and 3) Apply knowledge to understand tropical climate variability. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Radiative and convection: Radiative Processes in the Tropics, Surface Energy Balance, Top of the Atmosphere Net Radiation Fluxes, Dry and Moist Stability, Moist Convection
* General circulation in the tropics: Observed zonally averaged Tropical circulation, Theory of the Hadley Cell, Zonally asymmetric circulation features, seasonal variations, diurnal cycle, Observed aspects of the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ), ITCZ theory, Gill model, Heat lows, Tropical ocean circulation, ocean waves.
* Monsoons: Deﬁnition, Differential Heating and the Monsoon, Key Elements of the Asian Summer and Winter Monsoon, Onset and Withdrawal, Breaks in the Indian Monsoon
* El Nino and Southern Oscillation (ENSO): Observational aspect, air-sea interaction, Bjerknes feedback, teleconnection, ENSO modeling, Indian Ocean Dipole
* Madden Julian Oscillation (MJO): Observational aspect, Theory of MJO, Westerly wind bursts, Connection with ENSO
* Tropical Waves and Tropical Depressions (TD): Matsuno wave theory, convective coupled equatorial waves, easterly waves and TD-type disturbances, relationship with Tropical Cyclones (TC) genesis
* TC: Structure, Genesis, dynamics of TC movement, and intensiﬁcation, modeling and forecasting
* Tropical Squall Lines and Mesoscale Convective Systems (MCS): Observations of MCS and squall lines, dynamical aspects, Organization of Convection

courses.title: Air Pollution Science and Engineering
courses.description: This course will cover a variety of topics related to air pollution science and engineering. Topics include: indoor and outdoor air quality (including particulate matters (PM) and gases pollutants); air pollution measurement and statistics; air quality meteorology and dispersion models; principles and challenges of air pollution control and measurement.

* To understand the working principles of various air pollution monitoring instrumentation.
* To apply statistical tools and mathematical models to solve air pollutant dispersion problems.
* To apply various air pollution engineering approaches to solve air pollution issues.
* To gain a better understanding of current air pollution problems and control challenges.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Urban Climatology
courses.description: Human modifications to the surface of the Earth during urbanisation change most of the elements of climate and weather in the urban atmosphere. This course introduces the fundamentals of urban climatology and the processes caused by the changes in the surface environment, particularly focusing on how urban structures interact with the atmospheric environment. Numerical modelling and field techniques are introduced to understand the underlying processes resulting urban climatic phenomena. It also examines the implications on human comfort and climate-sensitive urban planning and design, as well as the relationship between cities and climate change.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5260
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Topic and Content/Fundamental concept**

Week 1 Lecture 1: Introduction to urbanisation and urban climate

Week 2 Lecture 2: Fundamentals of urban climatology I

* Urban boundary layer (UBL) and urban canopy layer (UCL)
* Urban climatic processes within UBL and UCL

Week 3 Lecture 3: Fundamentals of urban climatology II

* Heterogeneity of urban surface environment
* Atmospheric turbulence and exchange of energy and water

Week 4 Lecture 4: Urban energy balance I

* Anthropogenic heat flux
* Urban radiation balance

Week 5 Lecture 5: Urban energy balance II

* Urban canopy energy balance
* Urban neighbourhood energy balance

Week 6 Lab 1: Urban Multi-scale Environmental Predictor (UMEP): An integrated tool for city-based climate services

Week 7 Lecture 6: Urban heat islands – History and physical basis

* Detection of urban heat island: Luke Howard in 1810s
* Determinants of heat island magnitude and structure
* Diversity of urban heat island

Week 8 Lecture 7: Monitoring urban heat islands

* Ground-level meteorological measurements
* Mobile measurements
* Land surface temperature

Week 9 Lecture 8: Urban heat islands – Examples of different climatic regions

* Tropical climates: Singapore and India
* Sub-tropical climates: Hong Kong and South Africa
* Mediterranean climates: Greece and Spain
* High-latitude climates: Sweden and the United Kingdom

Week 10 Lecture 9: Urban climatic mapping

* Urban climatic maps – History, development, and applications
* Local climatic zones – Classification of surface environment

Week 11 Lecture 10: Application of urban climatology in climate-sensitive urban planning and design

* Why urban planning and design matters?
* Air Ventilation Assessment System
* Sustainable Building Design Guidelines

Week 12 Lab 2: Mapping of local climatic zones using WUDAPT methodology

Week 13 Lecture 11: Cities and climate change

courses.description: This course presents an introduction to the science of clouds. We begin with a descriptive cloud classification to introduce the different types of clouds in the Earth’s atmosphere. The roles of aerosols in cloud are also discussed. This is followed by cloud microphysics, describing the basic microphysical processes regarding formation, growth, shrinkage, breakup and fallout of cloud and precipitation particles. Next, different structures of precipitation and radar cloud sensing are presented. This will then be linked to cloud dynamics, associated with the fluid motions of the atmosphere.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5270.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students shall learn about a wide variety of physics and dynamics that control the occurrence, characteristics, and behavior of clouds. They shall understand the processes determining all the types of clouds in our atmosphere, over a wide range of spatial scales from microns to thousands of kilometers. They shall appreciate the importance of cloud to Earth’s climate. There are also be opportunities (e.g. outdoor cloud observation, cloud dynamics practicals both computationally and experimentally) where student can practice working effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic 1: Cloud Properties

Topic 2: Mixing and Convection in Clouds

Topic 3: Atmospheric Aerosols

Topic 4: Köhler Theory in Cloud Droplet Formation

Topic 5: Microphysical Processes in Warm Clouds

Topic 6: Microphysical Processes in Cold Clouds

Topic 7: Precipitation

Topic 8: Synoptic and Mesoscale Cloud Dynamics

Practical 1: Cloud Droplet Formation and Dust

Practical 2: Tornado Cloud Dynamics

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Practical Meteorology
courses.description: Practical Meteorology is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of various aspects of meteorology and their practical applications. The course will cover synoptic and mesoscale meteorology, satellite and radar meteorology, radiative transfer, lidar meteorology, aviation meteorology, and atmospheric instrumentation. Through a combination of lectures and case studies using instrument data, students will gain hands-on experience in analyzing and interpreting meteorological data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5280.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Analyze the concepts of synoptic and mesoscale meteorology and their impact on weather patterns and atmospheric processes.
2. Evaluate the principles and applications of satellite and radar meteorology in predicting weather conditions, detecting severe weather events, and investigating climate patterns.
3. Assess the fundamental principles of radiative transfer and its significance in maintaining energy balance, understanding climate change, and utilizing remote sensing techniques.
4. Examine the principles of lidar meteorology and its practical applications in profiling the atmosphere, studying aerosols, and analyzing the boundary layer.
5. Utilize atmospheric instrumentation data to conduct case studies, perform data analysis, and interpret findings to enhance understanding of meteorological phenomena.
6. Apply critical thinking and problem-solving skills to real-world scenarios by integrating meteorological concepts and theories into practical situations.
7. Evaluate the latest developments in practical meteorology from the literature to create individual presentations.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to synoptic and mesoscale meteorology:

1. Weather systems and their characteristics
2. Analysis and interpretation of weather maps
3. Atmospheric circulation patterns
4. Frontal systems and their impacts

2. Satellite and radar meteorology:

1. Satellite remote sensing principles and techniques

2. Interpretation of satellite imagery for weather analysis

3. Radar systems and their applications in severe weather detection

4. Doppler radar and its role in analysing storm dynamics

3. Radiative transfer:

1. Solar radiation and its interaction with the atmosphere

2. Greenhouse effect and climate change

3. Remote sensing applications of radiative transfer

4. Lidar meteorology:

1. Principles of lidar remote sensing

2. Lidar applications in atmospheric profiling

3. Aerosol studies using lidar

4. Boundary layer analysis with lidar

5. Aviation meteorology:

1. Meteorological factors affecting aviation operations

2. Weather hazards and their impact on flight safety

3. Aviation weather forecasting techniques

4. Application of meteorological information in flight planning and decision-making

6. Atmospheric instrumentation:

1. Introduction to meteorological instruments

2. Principles of measurement and calibration

3. Analysis and interpretation of instrument data for case studies

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Chemistry of Aquatic and Terrestrial Organic Matter

meetings.instructor: Professor CHOW Tat Shing

courses.description:
The course "Chemistry of Aquatic and Terrestrial Organic Matter" covers the study of the chemical composition, properties, and reactivity of organic matter in aquatic and terrestrial environments. Students will learn about the sources, transformation, and fate of organic matter in natural systems, as well as the impact of human activities on organic matter cycling. Topics may include the structure and function of organic molecules, biogeochemical processes involving organic matter, analytical techniques for studying organic matter, and the role of organic matter in ecosystem functioning. This course may also explore the implications of organic matter chemistry for environmental quality, carbon cycling, and nutrient dynamics in natural systems.

Advisory: 2 years college course works in Chemistry, Physics, and Mathematics is recommended.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:

1. Understand the chemical composition and properties of organic matter in aquatic and terrestrial environments.
2. Describe the sources, transformation, and fate of organic matter in natural systems.
3. Analyse the impact of human activities on organic matter cycling in ecosystems.
4. Apply analytical techniques to study organic matter in environmental samples.
5. Evaluate the role of organic matter in ecosystem functioning and environmental quality.
6. Discuss the implications of organic matter chemistry for carbon cycling and nutrient dynamics in natural systems.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to Organic Matter Chemistry

* Definition and characteristics of organic matter
* Sources of organic matter in aquatic and terrestrial environments

Week 2: Structure and Function of Organic Molecules

* Molecular composition and properties of organic matter
* Functional groups and reactivity of organic molecules

Week 3: Biogeochemical Processes Involving Organic Matter

* Decomposition and mineralization of organic matter
* Microbial transformations and nutrient cycling

Week 4: Analytical Techniques for Studying Organic Matter

* Spectroscopic methods (FTIR, NMR, UV-Vis)
* Chromatographic techniques (GC-MS, HPLC)

Week 5: Human Impacts on Organic Matter Cycling

* Pollution and contamination of organic matter
* Effects of land use change and climate change on organic matter dynamics

Week 6: Role of Organic Matter in Ecosystem Functioning

* Carbon sequestration and storage
* Nutrient retention and cycling in ecosystems

Week 7: Environmental Quality and Organic Matter Chemistry

* Organic matter as a source of contaminants
* Implications for water quality and ecosystem health

Week 8: Biogeochemical Cycling of Organic Matter in Aquatic Systems

* Organic matter dynamics in lakes, rivers, and oceans
* Impact of water chemistry on organic matter transformations

Week 9: Biogeochemical Cycling of Organic Matter in Terrestrial Systems

* Organic matter cycling in soils and terrestrial ecosystems
* Influence of vegetation and climate on organic matter dynamics

Week 10: Organic Matter and Climate Change

* Role of organic matter in carbon sequestration and greenhouse gas emissions
* Feedback mechanisms between organic matter cycling and climate

Week 11: Case Studies in Organic Matter Chemistry

* Application of organic matter chemistry principles to real-world environmental issues
* Case studies on organic matter in pollution remediation and ecosystem restoration

Week 12: Research Methods in Organic Matter Chemistry

* Designing and conducting experiments related to organic matter analysis
* Data interpretation and presentation of research findings

Week 13: Future Directions in Organic Matter Research

* Emerging trends and challenges in the study of organic matter
* Opportunities for further research and applications in organic matter chemistry

courses.description: This course presents the recent understanding and advancements in global biogeochemistry. The lectures are on a range of topics, covering major elemental cycles from the early Earth to future projections and from the lithosphere to the atmosphere, with an emphasis on the Ocean. Advanced concepts of application of biogeochemistry will further be discussed with an emphasis on environmental pollution and global climate change. The fundamentals of major elemental cycles like carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, oxygen, sulphur, and silicate will also be covered.

There is a basic course requirement in which we expect students to have fundamental knowledge in environmental science and chemistry.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:

1. Understand the key processes regulating elemental cycling in the environment, focusing on oceans.
2. Apply biogeochemistry concepts to global issues like pollution and climate change.
3. Critically evaluate research on major elemental cycles, including carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, oxygen, sulfur, and silicate.

courses.title: Statistical Methods and Data Analysis for Earth and Environmental Sciences
courses.description:
This course covers the theoretical basis and practical applications of data analysis relevant for earth system science. This course aims to introduce students to Earth and environmental data manipulation, from sampling, reading and writing, to statistical analysis and parameter estimation, to time series analysis, to plotting and visualization. Topics include: digital signal processing, sampling techniques; probability distributions; hypothesis testing; correlation analysis; linear and nonlinear regression; statistical forecasting, harmonic analysis and spectral analysis; principle component analysis; and geostatistics. Tutorials will be based on real geophysical examples including remote sensing and in situ observations, as well as model data.

Previous elementary coding experience in Python 3 is recommended.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5510
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will become knowledgeable about the acquisition, pre-processing and analysis of geophysical and environmental data, including remote sensing, in situ observation and model data. Students will acquire knowledge on techniques for data processing, including visualization methods and statistical analysis, and on the applications of these data and tools to geophysical and environmental problems. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principles, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students can also acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Exploratory Data Analysis
* Correlation Analysis
* Parametric Probability Distribution : Discrete
* Parametric Probability Distribution : Continuous
* Hypothesis Testing
* Frequentist Statistical Inference: Resampling Methods
* Statistical Forecasting: Simple Linear Regression
* Statistical Forecasting: Multiple Linear Regression, Non-Linear Regression
* Statistical Forecasting: Predictor Selection, Ensemble Forecasting
* Linear algebra and matrix inverse
* Quantifying preconceptions: Bayesian inference
* Quantifying preconceptions: Prior information
* Detecting periodicities: Sinusoidal functions and Fourier series
* Detecting periodicities: Complex Fourier series and Fourier transform
* The past influences the present: Convolution
* The past influences the present: Filters
* Cross-correlation
* Bandpass filters and windowing
* Filling in missing data
* Approximation
* Principal Component Analysis I
* Time Series Analysis
* Forecast Verification

courses.description: Remote sensing observations are critical for monitoring regional and global changes, determining spatial and temporal variability of the Earth System, and addressing fundamental global issues. This course introduces the basic physical principles of remote sensing, including electromagnetic waves and radiation, optical, microwave, and non-imaging remote sensing. It also presents key concepts and examples on remote sensing applications in Earth system science, such as the (atmosphere, lithosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere), and global changes. This course also provides computer-based lab exercises that facilitate the understanding of remote sensing principles and the processing of remote sensing data.

The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

1 Introduction, Remote sensing platforms

meetings.instructor: Professor ZHAI Shixian
Professor ZHAI Shixian

courses.description: This course introduces the basic principles of atmospheric modeling and provides hands-on practice to perform numerical simulations on University computing cluster. It begins with the concept of model and reviewing of physical and chemical processes in the atmosphere. After that, this course will cover introduction and hands-on practice of the three basic processes in atmospheric simulation: pre-processing data, modeling, and post-processing data. The pre-processing process refers to the preparation of data from various sources by different techniques such as the generation of emission inventories for atmospheric chemistry modeling. It then introduces numerical modeling basics such as “model equations and numerical approaches”. For post-processing, this course offers different skills in visualization of the model output and evaluation of model output against real-world observations. This course also introduces advanced knowledge in “model coupling” and “inverse modeling”. Finally, this course provides hands-on practice on simple model development experiments. During the course, we will cover basic Linux environment commands to perform the main tasks mentioned above. Overall, students can anticipate grasping basic modeling concepts and skills from this course, which are of great value to their future careers in both academia and industry.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5550.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Remember and explain the major chemical and physical processes that affect spatiotemporal variations of major atmospheric composition.
2. Explain the basic framework of atmospheric chemistry models including their input and output.
3. Understand what an emission inventory is and be able to pre-process emission inventory for atmospheric chemistry models.
4. Able to compile and run an atmospheric chemistry model.
5. Capable of visualizing model outputs and evaluating model outputs against observations.
6. Have the skills to sort out model structure by reading model codes and then revise model codes according to research needs.
courses.course_syllabus:
* The concept of model
* Processes in the atmosphere I - physical processes
* Processes in the atmosphere II - chemical processes
* Surface fluxes I - emission
* Surface fluxes II - deposition
* Model equations and numerical approaches
* Formulations of radiative, chemical, and aerosol rates
* Parameterization of subgrid-scale processes
* Post-processing model output data
* Model evaluation
* Model coupling
* Inverse modeling
* Model development experiments

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Integrated Earth and Environmental Field Study
courses.description: Understanding Earth processes and environmental changes requires the experience and skills gained from fieldwork. EESC5709 covers important aspects of field geology, including petrology, structural geology, tectonics, geophysics, and surficial processes. The principal goal of this course is to train students to recognize different lithological units and their spatial relationship in three dimensions, and to understand the related tectonic environment and formation mechanisms. This course will train the postgraduate students to master basic skills of reading and interpreting geological maps, using geological equipment (i.e., compass-clinometer, GPS receiver), and producing field notes and reports. Field projects include field observation and description, techniques for field data acquisition and analysis, sample collection, and geological map compilation. Field projects also focus on surficial processes, which occur over relatively short geological timescales but play important roles in environment and ecology. The field location, whether in mainland China or overseas, may change from year to year.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences or MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences.
courses.component:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:

1. Gain the basic skills of field work in geosciences.
2. Recognize different lithological units in the field, including sedimentary, metamorphic, volcanic and plutonic complexes.
3. Measure the geometry of different geological structures in variable scales.
4. Know how to use field equipment, such as GPS receivers and Compass-clinometer.
5. Be familiar with the techniques of field data acquisition and analysis.
6. Understand the standards of sample collection and description.
7. Be able to make field reports and compile a simple geological map.
8. Gain the capabilities of individual or team-oriented geological field work.
9. Be able to proposal their own scientific questions based on the field observations.

The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 3-4 pre-field lectures/tutorials for introducing geological background of the studied field area.
2. 10-12 days of field study and laboratory visit.
3. Individual field notes and reports are required.

* **Note:*** *Contents may vary depending on some conditions such as weather and safely.*

courses.description: In this course, a student is required to meet with his/her supervisor regularly who provides necessary guidance and supervision to write up a thesis and monitors the student's academic progress.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC8003.
courses.learning_outcomes: Development of research skills, including field and/or laboratory studies and data analysis as related to the students' thesis research.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Research skills
* Literature review
* Scientific writing
* Presentation
courses.feedback_evaluation: One-to-one meetings between student and thesis advisor
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by thesis advisor
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by thesis advisor
